PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa,
March 20, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a memorandum from the Surveys & Engineering Branch in which they state that Mr. Webb has recommended a new well at the Tsartlip Indian Day School.

It has been suggested that the appropriation for Indian education be responsible for the pump and well cover the estimated cost of which is $50.00. You may, therefore, incur an expenditure to the amount stated above and the account should reach the Department before the 31st instant.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.
Memorandum:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Water Supply Saanich Indian Reserves No 1, 2, 3, and 4.

A recent letter from Mr. Webb stated that the work authorized for these reserves had been completed at a cost of $516.83 leaving a balance of $25.17. He also forwarded a copy of a letter from Indian Agent Moore asking that surplus funds be expended on the purchase of 30 bags of cement to line a well on the Indian Reserve No 2 to be dug by certain Indians and lined by them, and the purchase and installation of a new pump and well cover at Tsarlip Indian Day School. The cost of cement at Saanich Reserves is $1.35 per bag and the estimated cost of pump and well cover is given by Mr. Moore as $50.00.

There is available in 71-60-119 an amount of $53.33 provided for work at Morley which will not be undertaken and enough of this can be transferred to 71-60-152 to enable either one of these items to be undertaken. If this transfer is approved, it is recommended that Mr. Webb be authorized to consult Mr. Indian Commissioner MacKay and to undertake whichever one of the two items is considered to be the more important, as the funds available are not sufficient for both. An early decision will be appreciated as the work, if undertaken, will have to be done this month.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer T.S. Mills.

Note: Surveys and Engineering have been instructed to purchase the 30 bags of cement for the well on Saanich No 2 Reserve.

These improvements consist of kalsomining the walls and ceiling of the class room, other minor improvements, and varnishing the school desks.

Sir:

I would respectfully refer to your letter of November 13th, 1940. File No. 152-14-5 wherein you were good enough to authorise the purchase of cocoa, milk and sugar for the pupils of the Tsartlip Indian Day School to an amount not to exceed $3.00 per month as from November 15th until March 31st, to be used to augment the midday lunch of these children.

I would ask the Department to be good enough to continue this service again this year because it worked out quite well during last winter, and according to the report of the Teacher, it was "a decided factor towards keeping the children healthy and contributed to their regular attendance at school".

I feel that if it helps the health of the children at all and encourages their attendance at school it will be money well spent. The total expenditure for the season will not exceed $15.00. An early reply will be appreciated.

Indian Affairs Branch, Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to request authority to purchase materials for a hot drink for the pupils of Tsartlip Indian Day School commencing October 1st, next and ending March 31st, 1944, amounting to $4.50, monthly.

In explanation of the extra amount asked for, I might say that the pupilage at this school this year is considerably increased and then on account of higher prices the money does not go so far.

With reference to the present set-up of teaching at this school, I might say that under date of the 3rd instant I made quite a lengthy report to the Indian Commissioner stating the improved conditions there and the splendid spirit which now exists over what we found previously, in fact ever since I came to the Agency. The Sister in charge, (Sister Maureen Regan) has done an excellent job in the short time she has been there and the attendance—even at this early date—has been much higher than at any time during the past year. I feel extremely confident that the future of the school is most promising and since I came here I never found the children so clean, attentive, well managed and happy as they were the day I visited. Altogether, I believe that—insofar as this school is concerned—the Department made a wise move to engage the Sister, particularly one so well qualified as Sister Maureen Regan is. This particular school, pupils and teachers alike, have been a headache to me for years and I really feel now that we will make progress. In my opinion at least the teacher deserves every encouragement from the Department and so far as I personally am concerned, I intend to go out of my way to help her in every way I possibly can.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver,

In reply to your letter above noted and further to mine of the 3rd. instant, I beg to attach hereto, in duplicate, a list of materials required for the proposed building for use at the Tsartlip school as a storeroom and toilet.

You will please note that the total cost will amount to $83.59 inclusive of a charge of $36.00 for labor in erection, which is at the rate of $6.00 per day. This building is urgently needed and I would recommend that the authority be granted as soon as possible.

The attendance at this school has been 100% since the day it opened and the children are as happy and contented as the flowers in June, all of which goes to show that if they like the teacher they will attend. I certainly feel that every assistance and encouragement should be given to this school and the Teacher as she is doing a grand job of work there.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
I wish to advise that I have just returned from a visit to the Tsartlip Indian Day School and met the Reverend Sister Maureen Regan and her co-teacher Reverend Sister Elizabeth Ann. It appears that there will be two teachers there in fact, while officially just one. The latter sister is teaching the primary class, using the entrance hall as a class room. This hall is the only store room we have in this school and it is piled up with garden and manual training supplies and tools, paper towels, toilet paper, janitor's brushes and supplies, school supplies and other impediments such as wash basins, pails etc. etc. all of which will show you how unsuitable it is for a class room. I should mention that it is only during certain subjects that the hall is being used, the rest of the time the pupils are in the class room with the other pupils.

I found that there was an attendance of 16 pupils each day since the school reopened and I have never seen the children so happy, clean and well behaved since I first visited that school and never found so large an attendance on any one day during the past year. My first impression of the Teachers is particularly good and I feel extremely confident of what the future of this school holds for the pupils and the Department regarding increased benefits. These two teachers appear particularly well qualified and seem to have the knack of handling children, although this is their first attempt at teaching Indians.

Sister Regan asked me about a separate toilet for the teachers and a small storeroom for the supplies at present piled in the hall of the school building, and I feel that the request should receive favourable consideration.

I wish to recommend that we erect a small building approximately 9 feet long, 6 feet wide and 7 feet high with a shed roof, which would act as a combined storeroom and toilet with a partition between them and which could be put up near the small woodshed and kept locked. No windows would be required, other than a small ventilator on the toilet side, and three ply roofing could be used instead of shingles. I think a building such as this could be put up for approximately $70.00 including the labor. If this recommendation receives favourable consideration by you I can get particulars of materials and labor costs. Please understand that this expenditure could not have been foreseen as the appointment of Sister Maureen Regan was not anticipated when estimates were submitted.

(R. H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letters of the 3rd and 24th ultimo requesting authority to expend $83.59 for the provision of a building for use as a store room and outbuilding at Tsartlip Indian Day School.

It will be noted that while the Department approved of the appointment of Sister Maureen Regan as teacher of the school, that she is accompanied by Sister Elizabeth Ann which appears to be, in part, the reason for the provision of this building in order that the small store room in the school can be used as an extra classroom.

In view of Mr. Moore's recommendation, I would recommend approval of the application if funds could be provided for this purpose. If the expenditure is approved, I would request advice in the matter by air mail as the uncertain state of the lumber market makes it imperative to accept quotations as early as possible if price changes are to be avoided.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.
Ottawa,

Additional seating accommodation is urgently required
for the Tsartlip Indian Day School. While in the Cowichan
Agency recently I called at this little school and was
gratified to find thirty pupils present out of an enrollment
of thirty-four. Much credit is due to the new teacher, Sister
Maureen Regan, for the increased attendance and the keen interest
being displayed by the Indian parents in the school.

The school is much too small for present and future
requirements and should be replaced by a new school as soon as
funds can be provided. Provision was made for this purpose in
the post-war program of new construction submitted to the
Department some time ago. In the meantime, it is suggested that
long desks be constructed at the back of the classroom to accom-
modate six to eight pupils now sharing single desks with other
pupils, the available space being too small for eight complete
single desks. A quotation on what is required is enclosed,
together with copy of a covering letter from Mr. Indian Agent
Moore. The cost seems high but is in line with prevailing rates
both for material and labour. It would be preferable, of course,
to furnish new regulation desks but in addition to lack of space
to accommodate them supplies are not available, at least in this
Province.

If funds are available, I would recommend that construction
of the desks required be approved.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.
Duncan, B.C.

I beg to submit herewith, two requisitions—one of which is in duplicate—received today from the Teacher of the Tsartlip School.

The pupilage of this school now stands at 34 and the little room is jammed to the door, which you can readily understand when you consider that the room was originally built intended to accommodate 16 pupils. These extra pupils have put an extra drain on all school supplies and makes a lot more work for the Teacher who finds that she needs a duplicator for getting out the work for the various classes as she has not got the time to put the work for each class on the board, nor in fact has she got the board space. I would therefore recommend that this be supplied.

The other requisition is for general supplies and it is noted that the prices were got from the Clarke & Stuart Co. catalogue as the only one available, I suppose, to the teacher. However, I think we can get the supplies in Victoria from one of the wholesale house for even less.

(R.H. Moore)

August 25th, 1944.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

With further reference to the opening of the new class room of the Tsartlip school, I wish to advise that the area on which will be used as a playground for the children and which lies between the Hall and the Church will have to have a coat of gravel on it before the wet weather starts. This particular piece of grounds is quite rough owing to the fact that wheel barrow loads of earth were dumped there and left in heaps, which will mean levelling before the gravel is put on.

The gravel will cost $1.00 per yard and it will cost another $6.00 to have the ground levelled beforehand. Kindly authorise this expenditure as soon as possible.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letters of the 25th and 30th of August, with reference to the grounds surrounding the church building which is being prepared for use as a second class room at the Tsartlip School. It will be noted that Mr. Moore recommends that the grounds be leveled and graveled at an approximate cost of $21.00.

In estimating the cost of preparing this building for use as a school room this expenditure was not taken into consideration and consequently was not provided for. Please advise if funds are available for this work.

For your information I enclose herewith two photos of the building in question.

For: D. M. MacKay,

I beg to submit herewith a quotation on material and labor for the erection of two swings and two teeter-totters at the Tsartlip School, Junior Rd., amounting to $52.15.

Indian Affairs Branch, Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to submit herewith an application for a Special Gasoline Category for:

Rev. Sister Maureen Regan, Teacher of the Tsartlip Indian Day School who drives back and forth each day to school, a distance of 30 miles. This trip is made 6 days each week. I would recommend that approval be given to this application the same as last year.

Dash board Licence slips are attached to both forms and which I would ask you to return as soon as possible.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 10, 1945.

Mr. R.H. Moore, Indian Agent,
Duncan, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, regarding special gasoline category for Sister Maureen Regan, I am sorry that nothing can be done about this matter as it is not our custom to sign these forms for teachers in Indian day schools.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 10th instant returning the application for special gasoline category for Rev. Sister Maureen Regan submitted by me under cover of letter of April 7th.

It would seem as if we are starting all over again this year where we left off last, and in this regard I would respectfully direct your attention to previous correspondence, listed below:

My letter to Department, March 30th, 1944, with enclosure.
Dr. McGill's letter to me, April 3rd, 1944, File:152-14-5.
My letter to Major MacKay, dated April 21st.
Major MacKay's letter to Dept., dated April 25th, File:3-11-2.
Dr. McGill's letter to me of May 10th, 1944, File: 152-14-5.

If you will please refer to the above correspondence you will note why the special category is requested and necessary. The conditions are exactly the same this year as last and I would request that the Department be good enough to give this further consideration, as I don't wish to return the application to the Rev. Sister until I am sure that I can not get assistance from the Department. In closing I would like to point out that every Rural school teacher in this Province who has to use a car to get to and from their school automatically receives a special gasoline category for this purpose, and it would appear as if Sister Maureen is in this class of employment. She has no other means of transportation and there is none available and 30 miles per day is too much to expect her to cycle. The form with dashboard license slip is returned herewith.

(P.H. Moore) Indian Agent.
April 10, 1945.

R. H Moore, Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C.

Sister Regan's application has been submitted for signature by Mr. Jackson, the certificate having been amended for the purpose.

This application is not in the category of those that require Mr. Jackson's signature, which comprises only Department cars and trucks, and cars personally owned and operated on a mileage basis by employees. It is obvious that this office is not in possession of any record that would warrant the signing of certificate No. 2.

The Regional Oil Controller should be informed of this as he is probably under the impression that Sister Regan is one of those for whom it has been arranged that the Chief Executive Assistant would sign certificate No. 2. Any responsible local resident conversant with the facts may sign the certificate which applies to her case, and the Oil Controller will act upon such if he is informed as above.

Your reference to last year's correspondence is noted. At that time the clerk who attends to these matters was in hospital and the matter was efficiently taken care of by his stenographer notwithstanding that she was not familiar with the requirements.

Acting Director.

Your File #3-11-12 October 13th, 1944

In reply to your letter above noted, relative to gasoline for Sister Maureen Regan of the Tsartlip School, I wish to say that I conveyed the information to the Reverend Sister, as set out in your letter and have now received her reply which says in part:

"With regard to the gasoline question: On April 1, 1944 I applied for gasoline to be used for school purposes during the fiscal year from March 31, 1944 to March 31, 1945. Due to some misunderstanding I was not issued a Ration Coupon Book until the latter part of May. Which book, marked "Special A" containing 60 units, and marked "This is your Final Book". In the meantime, I was obliged to use for school driving the "AA" coupons allowed for ordinary driving.

Our car, being a 1933 model, averages 15 miles per gallon of gasoline. When I applied April 1st, for gasoline, this is how I stood regarding mileage, etc.:

From March 1944 - March 1945 ........ 45 school weeks
Mileage @ 25 miles per day ------------ 5,625 miles
The latter part of May we were issued 60 units
Mileage on 60 units .......... 2700 miles.

At present I have on hand 25 units
Mileage on 25 units------------------ 1,125 miles.
This year our mileage averages 26 miles per day, due to the fact that the Junior Room is located ½ mile from the Senior Room.

I have on hand units enough to last 43 days.
I might mention that during the latter part of July we taught "Vacation School" in Saanichton which necessitated our using the car for that week."
Kindly advise further in this regard and see if this Teacher is going to get more gasoline. If she is not, please have the Controllet so advise.

(R. H. Moore)
Indian Agent.
DUNCAN, B. G.
April 24, 1945.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

Referring to previous correspondence relating to the application of Sister Maureen Regan for a Special Gasoline Category, as instructed the form was sent to Ottawa and returned since the Department could not see its way clear to recommend any additional gasoline. On April 16th I again wrote Ottawa (as per copy of letter attached) giving full details and referring to correspondence on the matter with you in 1944. I am now in receipt of a reply (copy also attached) which I trust you will find self-explanatory.

You will note from my letter that I returned the application form along with the dash-board licence slips, but so far the dash-board slip has not been returned by Ottawa and I am unable to have a new form submitted until this is done.

In the meantime, the Reverend Sister is in need of gasoline and it occurred to me that you, as Senior Department Official, might sign this application for the Officer of the Oil Controller, or if not then it can be signed, as suggested by the Department, by some local resident. However, it would seem to me that an official of this Department would be in a much better position to state the facts than an outsider, since Sister Maureen Regan is employed by us.

Your comments on the matter will be appreciated.

R.H. MOORE,
Indian Agent.
April 26th, 1945.

R. H. Moore, Esq., Indian Agent, Duncan, B.C.

Acknowledging your letter of the 26th instant I would advise that I have asked the Department to airmail you Sister Maureen Regan's Provincial automobile license slip and application.

In view of the Department's letter of the 19th instant addressed to you on this subject in which it is stated that any local resident conversant with the facts may sign the certificate I do not consider it was intended to place this responsibility on any official of this office. Apparently the automobile is also used for purposes other than those of this Department as in your letter of October 20th, 1944, you quote from the Reverend Sister's letter, "during the latter part of July we taught 'Vacation School' in Saanichton which necessitated our using the car for that week." You will also note that she states in this letter that she is using an old 1933 model car averaging only fifteen miles per gallon and that they are travelling 26 miles a day, return mileage from Victoria to the school.

In view of the critical shortage of gasoline and rubber, it occurs to me that rather than consume these essentials in a mechanically inefficient vehicle the Rev. Sisters should explore the possibility of securing accommodation in the neighbourhood of the school.

In any event, I regret that this office is not in a position to meet your request that we endorse the application.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Indian Affairs, (RG 10, Volume 6409, file 839-5, part 3)
Indian School Fire Caused By Gasoline

Such a charge was made to the Tsartlip School on the Dredwood Indian Reserve, West Saanich Road, at 8:40 this morning when a stove exploded after gasoline had been used to start a fire, Saanich firemen reported.

Fire Chief Joe Law, who attended with equipment from his department, said the blaze was confined to a small area.

It was fortunate, he said, that the whole school was not burned to the ground.
Duncan, B.C.

January 2nd, 1946

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

I beg to apply for authority to purchase 5 (five) Guardene Fire Extinguishers, 2½ gall. capacity (Soda & Acid) for the following schools at the price of $15.50 each F.B.B. Victoria, Sales Tax included. Total: $77.50

Tsartlip Indian Day School, Senior room. 1 Extinguisher.
" " " " Junior room 1 "
Saanich Indian Day school 1 "
Songhees " " " 1 "
Nanaimo " " " 1 "

During the last two months there have been small fires occurring in two of the above schools, Tsartlip Sr. and Saanich Indian Day, and from what I understand we were most fortunate in not losing both buildings.

The damage to the Saanich Day school building was taken care of by the Church authorities, who own the building, but even the loss to this Department would be considerable from equipment, had the building been seriously damaged.

Tsartlip school Sr. room was scorched a little inside the door and along the baseboards when oil which one of the pupils was using to light the fire exploded and caused slight damage, the extent of which I don't know exactly as it was reported about 10 days ago and I have not been to the school since I returned to duty. As soon as I have been down I will report further. In the meantime I would like to have advice regarding the possibility of getting the extinguishers as requested.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of January 2nd in connection with the proposed supply of fire extinguishers to the Tsartlip, Saanich, Songhees and Nenaimo Indian Day Schools. It is understood that the Guardene Fire Extinguishers are the general purpose type and would be suitable for use in Day Schools and I would recommend that authority be granted for an expenditure of $77.50 for the purchase of five extinguishers if funds are available.

I am writing to Mr. Indian Agent Moore in connection with the use of oil for starting fires in Indian Day Schools and warning him against this practice.

For D. M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Ottawa, January 16, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 8th instant, the Department approves the expenditure of $77.50 for the purchase of fire extinguishers to be placed in the Day Schools of the Cowichan Agency.

I note that it is the intention to buy 2½-gallon extinguishers. I have always felt that the one quart size would be just as good at a day school, especially where there are female teachers. Extinguishers of the size mentioned are much handier to use when occasion arises.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

In reply to your letter above noted, I would advise that I visited the Tsartlip school last week and find that apart from a little discourcuration and slight scorching to one corner of the baseboard and about half the inside of the inner door, there was no damage at all done to the building or any of the contents.

I venture to say that the door and baseboard can be scraped and restained and varnished again at a cost of not more than $15.00 and I would ask that authority be given to me to have Mitchell & Anderson do this job as soon as possible.

I feel that the use of oil for lighting the fire will never be used again in this school as I feel that they have all learned their lesson rather thoroughly.

While I am on this subject I would ask that the shipment of the new stove for this school from Vancouver be expedited as the one in use at present is a menace to the building and occupants, as both sides are burned through.

R.H. Moore,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Further to my letter of January 8th in connection with the proposed supply of fire extinguishers for various schools in the Cowichan Agency, and in particular to that part of Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of January 2nd dealing with fire damage to the senior room of the Tsartlip school, I am enclosing Mr. Moore's letter of January 17th from which it will be noted that the necessary repairs will cost approximately $15.00. I have authorized Mr. Moore to have this work proceeded with, which action I trust has your approval.

D. M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Philip Phelan,

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of January 15th in connection with seating accommodation at the Tsartlip Indian Day School. January 15th, 1946

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

During a recent visit to the Tsartlip I.D. school, junior room, it was brought to my attention that there is a definite shortage of desks. There are 20 pupils in attendance and only accommodation for 15 comfortably, although by putting four pupils in a desk intended for three they can seat 17, which is too crowded.

You will remember that some of the desks there were made by Mitchell & Anderson and are after the old style of desks where three or four children sit together, this was done to conserve space when we had only the one school on that reserve. Since then we had two of those desks cut in half which is a definite improvement, but there are still two others which should be cut so that we can get the maximum seating capacity out of them. However, even with that we will still have to have 4 #2. desks complete, that is four fronts & four backs. The reason I am asking for size 2 for the junior room is that some of the children in the low grades are big and old enough to be in the senior room but on account of poor, and in some cases no, attendance at school when they came of school age meant no progress.

These desks should be shipped direct to the following address:

The Teacher, Tsartlip I.D. School, Jr. Room,
C/O. The R.C. Rectory,
West Road, Saanichton, B.C.,
as soon as conveniently possible.

I would also ask for authority to have the two long desks cut and made into fours which will entail putting in extra legs at an approximate cost of $15.00.

R.H. Moore, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 5, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the first instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $70.00 for the purchase of additional desks for the Tsartlip School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reference your letter above noted I wish to advise that during a recent visit to Victoria I tried to get a suitable wood burning circulating heater for the Tsartlip School but was unable to do so and the stores and wholesalers were unable to give me an approximate date of when they might be expected.

I was wondering how the stock of Gordon and Belyea is and if our chance of getting the heater from them by the end of this month is still good. If not I would suggest that one of the Duo-Therm oil heaters be installed at an approximate cost of $67.00. It seems to me that these oil heaters are much more satisfactory for Indian schools, or in fact any one room schools than coal or wood and the cost of operation is certainly no higher.

During a recent visit to the Deep Bay Public school I noticed that they had one there and the teacher was high in her praise of its efficiency and simplicity of control.

R. H. Moore

Replying to your letter of above date and file number I would say that the price of $67.00 given in my letter of the 13th ultimo was the wholesale price on a smaller heater, which on further investigation was considered too small for the school. The size quoted on here-with has almost twice the heating capacity, but of course is the retail price from Mitchell and Anderson Hardware of Sidney, who will build the platform or stand for the drum of oil and install the stove properly for $123.38 which is less than quoted us by the McDowell Co. in Victoria on a different make of stove of the same size. So far I have not received a written quotation from McDowell, although I have asked for it twice since you were over.

Your File 152-14-5

I have to refer to Mr. Nelson's letter of November 17th, 1945, authorizing the purchase of a new heater for the Tsartlip Indian Day School at an approximate cost of $40.00.

We have been unsuccessful in securing delivery of a suitable heater and Mr. Indian Agent Moore, in his letters of March 15th and April 13th attached, suggests that consideration be given to the installation of a Duo Therm oil heater. It will be noted that Mr. Moore considers that an oil heater would be much more satisfactory for use in Indian Day Schools and that the cost of operation in his Agency would be no more than for coal and wood heaters. The total cost of a suitable Duo Therm oil heater, completely installed, with a 40-gallon drum of fuel oil, would be $123.38, and I would recommend that the Department authorize this expenditure.

With reference to your letter of the 11th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $24.62 for the construction of a basketball court at the Tsartlip Indian Day School.

Dept. of Mines & Resources

During my recent visits to the Tsartlip Indian Day School, Senior Room, I have been struck by the efficiency displayed by Sister Elizabeth Marie in teaching sewing and other arts to her pupils. The same thing applies to the Saanich Indian Day School which is being taught by Sister Socorro. These Sisters are most interested in trying to get the pupils to make their own clothes and have requested that this Department be good enough to supply a sewing machine for each of the two schools (Tsartlip Senior and Saanich Indian Day Schools). I would recommend that the Department procure these machines and have them shipped direct to the schools concerned the addresses of which follow:

Teacher  
Saanich Indian Day School  
Saanich I.R. #2  
Saanichton, B.C.

Teacher  
Tsartlip Indian Day School - Senior Room  
Saanich I.R. #1  
Brentwood Bay, B.C.

I am arranging to send some old Army and Airforce clothing which I have on hand, down to these schools so that the teachers may instruct their pupils in remodelling them for their own use. Trusting that you may give this request favourable consideration.

R. H. Moore  
Indian Agent.
Duncan, B.C.
October 17th, 1946.

Major D. M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Post Office Box 70
Vancouver, B.C.

This is to advise that I have made arrangements with Joe Bartleman of the Saanich #1 Reserve to plow a garden plot at the Tsartlip Indian Day School as well as slash and grub approximately 1½ acres of land adjoining the school which is to be used for a playground and basketball court. I estimate that the sum of $45.00 will be required to pay Bartleman for this work and I would ask that you be good enough to give me the necessary authority as soon as possible. As a matter of fact he has already plowed the garden as I wanted it done before the weather broke.

R. H. Moore
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of October 17th in connection with a proposed expenditure of $45.00 for clearing land adjoining the Tsartlip Indian Day School building to provide a suitable playground and basketball court, and for plowing the school garden.

I may say that this school building is more or less surrounded by brush, a condition which is not desirable, and I would recommend approval of the expenditure requested.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,

Ottawa, March 7th, 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the first instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $50.00 for levelling the ground at the Tsartlip Indian Day School.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Your file 152-14-5 (W.T.L)

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of October 21st authorizing an expenditure of $24.82 for the construction of a basketball court at the Tsartlip Indian Day School, I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of February 25th wherein he requests that a further expenditure of $50.00 be authorized for levelling the basketball court.

Mr. Moore's letter indicates that if the work is to be done it would be advisable to take advantage of the services of Mr. J.D. Kissinger who is working with a bulldozer in the vicinity, and if funds are available I would recommend that Mr. Moore be authorized to have the work done.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,
Post Office Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.

You will please remember that you authorized some months ago certain materials and labor charges in connection with the erection of a Basketball Court at the Tsartlip Senior School. The backboards, baskets, etc., have all been put in but owing to the rather rough ground, it is difficult, and in fact dangerous for the pupils to play there due to the unevenness of the ground which might cause a strain or even a break of some child's leg.

However, I have been endeavouring for some time to get someone with a bulldozer to go in and level off the ground, and just managed to get a quotation from Mr. John D. Kissinger to clear the ground of roots and level the court as well as depositing the extra soil around the yard where needed, for the sum of $50.00. This is a particularly reasonable figure and if we had to bring in a machine, it would cost us twice as much but it so happens that this man is working near there and will not have to charge much for his moving time.

An early reply will be appreciated.

R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM.

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.
From: Inspector of Indian Schools.

I refer to the application of Mr. R.H. Moore for an allowance to enable pupils from the Cole Bay Indian Reserve to be transported to the Tsartlip Indian Day School.

It is recommended that this application be granted, with the reservation that this allowance will be withdrawn should the number of pupils drop below four.

It is also suggested that an attendance report by the senior teacher be attached to the Voucher.

R.F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools.
In reply to your letter above noted, I attach, herewith, in duplicate, a list of Indian children belonging to the Pauquachin Band, which will give you the information requested.

Personally, I feel that payment on a per capita attendance basis is hardly fair to the operator owing to the fact that it costs exactly the same to take one child to school as it would to take twenty. There is the same mileage, same wear and tear on the truck, and the same length of time required. Furthermore, if there happens to be any sickness among the Indian children they would have to stay home, which is certainly no fault of the operator; but, at the same time, he would be penalized. If you insist on an attendance basis of pay we might as well forget the whole matter as the Indian I have in mind to run the bus would not be interested other than on a straight monthly rate.

Finally, the Indian, Walter Williams, is prepared to comply with Provincial requirements insofar as Provincial Licence is concerned, also insurance and inspection of vehicle.

R. H. Moore
Indian Agent.

RHME:EL
Enc1.2.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's application of the 5th inst. for provision of transportation for the children of Seanich I.R. No. 3 (Coele Bay) to the Tsartlip Indian Day School, a distance of about six miles each way in an Indian automobile, together with a memorandum of the 14th inst. by Inspector Davey.

You will note that the cost will amount to approximately $86.00 a month for the conveyance of an estimated eight children.

The Department will no doubt recall the difficulty we experienced in this Agency for similar transportation for the Nanaimo children, it having to be finally abandoned as the cost per pupil became too high.

However, I would recommend that this application be given a trial on the basis that should the average attendance fall off the project be reconsidered and definitely abandoned when it falls below an average of four pupils in any one month.

I would also suggest that the Reverend Principal's certificate of pupils conveyed by this service be submitted with each voucher.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

FROM: D. S. GODWIN
Well Driller

Oct. 9th/47.

Mr. R. H. Moore,
Indian Agent,
DUNCAN, V. I.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of Oct. 2nd, 47. The charge for drilling a well would be five dollars ($5.00) per foot with a minimum cost of $150.00 or 30 feet of drilling.

The above charge per foot includes all necessary casing to reach from surface to bed-rock; when drilling in bed rock no casing is required as the rock forms its own casing. In regard to the probable depth, my guess would be 100 feet more or less - however I might be far from the mark as the wells in that vicinity vary in depth considerably.

I think it would be advisable to employ a diviner; his charge would be approximately $10.00, I recommend Mr. A.J.A. Bell, 1234 Pike Street, Victoria.

Yours truly,

Signed "D. S. Godwin"

(LS)
Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Post Office Box 70,
VANCOUVER, B. C.

Replying to your above letter, I wish to attach, herewith, in duplicate, a copy of a letter recently received from Mr. Godwin in reply to one I sent him making enquiries as to the cost of drilling a well at the Tsartlip Indian Day School, which I hope may be found self-explanatory.

If there is any money available now I would recommend that the well be drilled as soon as possible and before the ground gets sodden with rain.

We should figure on a cost of from $510.00 to $1,010.00, depending on the depth, including the Diviner's fee. It might so happen that we will be lucky and strike a satisfactory flow at less than one hundred feet, but it is hardly likely.

R. H. MOORE
Indian Agent.

RHM:EL
Enc.2.
Oct. 22, 1947.

Airmail:

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Reference is made in District School Inspector Davey's recent report covering his inspection of the Tsartlip Indian Day School to the lack of an adequate water supply.

I am enclosing herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of October 15th in this connection, from which you will note that the cost of drilling a well at this school may run as high as $1,010.00. No provision was made in the estimates for this expenditure, and it is thought that the funds allotted for the construction of new schools would be required elsewhere. In any case it would appear to me that, in view of the possible extent of the expenditure involved, this is a matter which should be investigated by the Surveys and Engineering Branch.

for D. M. MacKay
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Encl.
-ms.

Bernard F. Heary

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS & ENGINEERING BRANCH

Indian Commissioner MacKay writes that a well is required at the above mentioned school. Preliminary estimates indicate that an expenditure of over $1,000.00 might be necessary.

The Commissioner considers this amount excessive and we would appreciate it if you could arrange to have one of your officers visit the school and let us have a report.

Director.

Re: Voucher No. 85 - Jan. 26, 1948

In reply to your letter, date and file number above noted, I wish to advise that I quite appreciate the fact that the existing set-up in this school is unusual — all of which was explained in detail before the building was taken over as a school room. Major MacKay and Inspector Coleman saw the building and had at least two interviews with the then Priest in charge, before final arrangements were made.

Several months after we commenced to use the Hall I explained the lighting situation, in letters, to Major MacKay — dated January 12th and February 2nd, 1945 — to which the Commissioner replied on February 6th, 1945, authorizing payment of the account at the rate of $20.00 for the entire Winter Season — from November to February.

In the Fall of 1945 the Priest was replaced by the present incumbent who was totally unaware of the arrangements made by his predecessor, with this Department, and it was not until a few weeks ago that he came to me to see why we had not paid the light bill for the Winters of 1945 and 46 and 1946-47. I simply told him that he had not submitted any accounts and that I assumed the Church was making a donation to the Department — and so let sleeping dogs lie. He assured me this was not so and immediately sent accounts for the two years.

The Church authorities do not wish a separate meter installed as the Rectory, Church, and Hall are all on one meter. If such an installation was to be made it would not help any as the building is used frequently for ordinary parish Church meetings and social gatherings.

Personally, I feel that the present arrangement is much less expensive than if we had a meter. Certainly no one can complain that a twenty dollar ($20.00) per annum light bill is expensive.

R. H. MOORE
Indian Agent.

As you will remember, the agreement entered upon between the Department of Indian Affairs and the Catholic Authorities in Saanich, by which the parish hall would be used as a junior class room to the West Saanich Indian Day School, was an emergency measure.

Although the Church Authorities are prepared to leave the hall at the disposal of the Department, as long as new quarters will not be available, they feel that, owing to high cost of material and labor, the present rent of $10.00 is no more adequate.

October 19, 1948.

Mr. R.H. Moore,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Duncan, B.C.

We have your letter of September 28th requesting authority for expenditures in connection with sewing materials for the Tsartlip and Saanich Indian Day School.

We cannot understand why you request such heavy expenditures. We are quite prepared to supply a reasonable amount for the teaching of sewing to the girls, but it is not our intention to provide material that will probably be used by various Indians on the reserve. Extract from an Agricultural Survey - Cowichan Agency, dated May 20th, 1948,

I made several enquiries regarding the 7000 strawberry plants supplied to five pupils of the Tsartlip School and, due to planting the strawberries on freshly-plowed sod and very little if any supervision during the summer, the grass and weeds took over in every case excepting Jack Paul's patch who kept it in good shape. Sister Elizabeth Marie who started this project asked the J. Paul be given more strawberry plants this fall but I pointed out to her that, since he had planted 1500 plants last spring, he would be able to get sufficient new plants off his own patch to plant any additional acreage that he could handle. In future when projects such as this are contemplated, I would recommend that not more than 500 plants be given and only to those who have land that was cultivated the previous year.

(Sgd) W. J. McGregor,

MEMORANDUM

Ottawa April 1st, 1949.

Re: Water Supply - Tsartlip Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency.

Attached in duplicate is a report by Mr. Barrass dated March 10, 1949, dealing with the proposed well for the above Indian School.

In a covering letter Mr. Webb writes as follows:

"With regard to a request for investigation of possibilities of obtaining water for Tsartlip Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, I am now able to provide a report in triplicate in this connection by Mr. C.W. Barrass, dated March 10, 1949.

It would appear from this report that a ground water supply can only be obtained at considerable depth. Shallow wells have in most instances dried up early in the season. Mr. Barrass suggests that the probable cost of a drilled well near the school site might be $715. for a depth of 130 feet. It appears that there is a reasonable certainty of securing water at that depth.

Mr. Barrass has further investigated the possibilities of providing power for operating a pump. This will be rather expensive owing to the necessity of constructing the power line for a distance of one-half mile. It appears that the yield from the aquifer is very small and that if a greater distribution was required, possibly to the Indian village, elevated tanks will be required, as pressure tank service would not likely be suitable due to the low pumping rate. It would not appear that there is any alternative to a well as a source of supply for this school.

Duplicate copies of this report are being forwarded to Mr. Arneil for his information."

The well is estimated to cost $715.00, but the cost of delivery to the school and possibly to the reserve, has not been investigated, as this might depend to some extent on the amount of water found to be available when the well has been drilled.

If Indian Affairs will advise whether they require domestic water to be delivered to the Reserve as well as to the school, and also whether they require electric power to be delivered to the Village, we will investigate further.

Memorandum to Mr. Webb:

Re: Water Supply
Tsartlip Indian Day School
Saanich I.R. No. 1
Cowichan Agency, B.C.

Pursuant to your instructions of November 27, 1948, I visited the above reserve with the object of determining the possibility of drilling for water at the Tsartlip school. The information obtained and the subsequent proposals are set forth in the following memorandum.

General

1. Saanich I.R. 1

The reserve is fourteen miles north of Victoria in the South Saanich Municipality. The majority of the twenty-two dwellings on the reserve are located between the West Saanich Road and Saanich Inlet, a distance of approximately 1600 feet. The difference in elevation between the road and the inlet is about 150 feet. In October, 1948, the population was 164 persons.

2. Educational Facilities

The existing facilities consist of a small wood frame school building with a seating capacity of 15, situated east of the main road in the centre of the reserve. The limited capacity of this building is augmented by the use of a church three-quarters of a mile north of the school which is rented by the Indian Department.

The Educational Branch of the Indian Affairs Department are intending to construct an additional two room school which will have a seating capacity for 70 pupils. The site of this structure is to be determined by the location of the source of water supply. The Department prefers a site adjacent to the present building as it is the centre of the reserve and provides ample space for playground facilities.
Domestic Water Supply

All water for domestic use on the reserve and adjacent property is derived from wells. In the vicinity of the proposed site there are three dug wells on reserve lands and five drilled wells on private property. One of the dug wells is adjacent to the present school but unfortunately it is dry throughout the year. The accompanying sketch plan illustrates the relative position, yield, and depth of the wells in respect to the school site. The average drilled well in the vicinity of the school has a depth of 95 feet and a yield of 150 gallons per hour.

Recommendations

There is ample evidence that a well drilled adjacent to the site of the present school will be successful and it is therefore recommended that funds be allotted for its installation. It is estimated that the cost of drilling and casing will be $715.00. (See Appendix I).

Supplement to the Above Recommendation

The distribution and use of the well proposed above naturally depends upon its yield. The main purpose of the inspection of the reserve was to determine the feasibility of drilling for water at the proposed school site, however the cost of power for a pump and the means by which the water may be delivered under pressure encumbers other factors which are enumerated in the following paragraphs.

The source of water for over 160 residents on this reserve consists of three dug wells, only one of which yields consistently. This well is the only source of domestic water for the entire Indian Village. If the yield of the proposed well is sufficient, it may be possible, due to the topography of the reserve, to supply both the school and the Indian resident dwellings by gravity flow from an elevated storage tank.
The factors determining the further development of the well then are as follows:

1. Supplying the School with Domestic Water Service.

   a. Electric Power

   The British Columbia Electric Company Ltd.'s estimate of the approximate cost for extending their distribution lines from Stelly Crossing (see plan) to the Indian School is approximately $740.00. Their calculations for the above figure assumed the use of 1 KW of lighting equipment and a single phase motor not larger than 2 H.P. Against this total the British Columbia Electric Railway Company will credit the first two years revenue, which would be in the neighbourhood of $50.00, resulting in a net cost of $690.00.

   If the Department provided electric service to the Indian residents, the charge for the extension from Stelly Crossing would be under another section of the Public Utilities Commission Tariff.

   b. Storage and Delivery under Pressure

   As the anticipated well yield is only 150 U.S. gph (2½ U.S. gpm.) a pressure tank will not be suitable. To supply water under pressure, an elevated storage tank will have to be constructed, its capacity being determined by the number and type of plumbing fixtures intended for the new school.

2. Supplying the School and the Indian Village with Domestic Water Service.

   To supply the Indian day school and village jointly will require a larger capacity storage tank than above at approximately the same elevation. In this case two wells in parallel, each with a yield of 150 gph, will be required if complete plumbing facilities are installed in the school.

Cyril W. Barrass, B.A.Sc.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter dated 26th February, telling me that it is the Department's intention to open a day-school on Seabird Island Reserve. Also that your Agent reports the presence of 36 children of school age in the immediate vicinity.

Sir,

Having further reference to letter number 165-5-1 dated February 27th, in connection with starting a day school on Seabird Island Reserve.

As instructed by you I wrote to Father Welch with a view of obtaining a Roman Catholic teacher for this school, but up to the present have had no reply.

I also wrote to Mr. Inspector Cairns and he tells me that there are no Roman Catholic teachers available to his knowledge.

The Indians of this band being desirous of getting this school started immediately have forwarded me a petition asking that any teacher available will be quite satisfactory to them, in order to get the school started.

The one greatest drawback of getting a teacher for a school like this, is the small salary paid. The Department, according to their letter, is only offering from $600 to $800 per year, according to qualifications. Now if we get a teacher, he or she will have to board in Agassiz, and will have to pay anywhere from $35 to $40 per month for board. Presuming that they get board for $35, which is very exceptional, this would only leave $15.00 a month to take oneself on. Just now there is a stir among the Indians regarding school affairs and they have expressed the desire to have a change of teachers. This can be brought about by giving Mrs. Carpentier sufficient notice. She would like to remain in the school until June 30th and I would, therefore, recommend that Mrs. Carpentier be allowed to finish her work for the year.

During my visit to the Seabird Indian Day School, some five or six of the men were present at the examination. I explained to them that Mrs. Carpentier would, in all probability, resign her position to take effect June 30th, 1928. Mrs. Mary E. Carpentier has been faithful in the discharge of her duties as a teacher. She has been extremely kind to the pupils and, notwithstanding the fact that the attendance has been irregular, progress has been made. The Indians spoke kindly of Mrs. Carpentier.

Mrs. Carpentier asked me if she could obtain a leave of absence for one year, that is to make it possible for Mrs. Carpentier at the end of a year to make application should there be a vacancy. This, of course, will come up for review about the 30th of June, 1928.
Miss Ruth Young, an expert Primary teacher, was present at the examination and taught a model lesson for the benefit of both teacher and pupils. It appeared to me that Mrs. Carpentier has lost her interest, to some extent, in the pupils. However, I would like to give her a further trial. At the end of a month or two, I will visit the school again and be in a position to give recommendations.

It may be necessary to consider the matter of a change of teachers unless results are evident.

The attendance and the work generally are not satisfactory. Mrs. Carpentier seems to have lost her grip and is not getting the co-operation of the parents, as she should.

Dear Sir,

I have received your letter informing me that my services will not be required after June 30th 1937, and must say that I think it very unjust that I am dismissed in this way without being given an opportunity of speaking one word for myself.

You will no doubt remember that on the occasion of your first visit to this school after I came here (only a few days after I took charge) I told you that the children were very far behind in the work of their grades, very sullen, very bad mannered, very badly spoken and that their writing was a disgrace. I also said that under the circumstances I was bound to receive very unfavourable reports from Capt. Barry, and that I would be blamed for all the faults of the children, although in no way responsible. You agreed with me regarding the manners and speech and said that I would have a hard task changing them. I may say that after two years hard work I have succeeded and most of the children are now well spoken and have nice manners. As to the schoolwork I have exercise books which were in use here before my time which will prove what I say is correct.

Each time Capt. Barry has inspected the school, although he did not say anything, I could tell that he was not very well impressed by the work of the higher grades, neither was I, and it is only now that I am getting the children where I want them. As to Grades 1 and 2, Capt. Barry has always told me that they were excellent, and as they are the children I started in school I think I should be judged by their work as they are the most important grades in any school, being the foundation on which all the rest of the schoolwork is built.

I shall be glad if you will forward a copy of this letter to Ottawa and ask that an impartial official of the Department investigate this and prove if I am right or wrong. I think that after hearing my side of the question they cannot in common justice refuse to do so.

Yours truly,

A. Strang Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23rd ultimo and also Inspector Barry's report on the Seabird Island Indian Day School, sent forward therewith.

I note with interest Inspector Barry's recommendation, approved by yourself,- that the salary of Miss Boeur, the teacher in charge of this school, be increased. I feel confident, however, that it would be simply a waste of time for me to recommend a salary increase in this case, in view of the comparatively small enrolment at this school and the low average attendance. I note that when Inspector Barry visited the school there were only three boys and three girls present and that the average attendance for this school year amounts to only 5.4. This condition is wholly unsatisfactory to the Department, and in view of the conditions now confronting us, not only this school but other schools where the attendance is unsatisfactory should be very carefully reviewed by the Inspector, acting under specific instructions from yourself. I feel confident that the Minister will expect you to take such action.

Would it be possible, therefore, to have from you a recommendation in respect to this and other schools, expressing an opinion on,-

Dear Major MacKay:

With reference to the attached file I may say that I have read Department letter 165-8-1 with some care.

The instructions with regard to Miss Boeur will be followed should she again mention the question of salary increase. If you consider that Mr. Indian agent Strong should be informed of the Department's decision in this case, you will no doubt take the necessary action.

The preliminary work on the survey of small Indian schools suggested by Mr. Hoey has been completed during the past weeks as I had a few minutes to spare from time to time.

The possible increase in attendance at some of these schools has been discussed with Church officials in a few cases, mainly to enable me to obtain some idea of the reaction to be expected should one or more schools be closed.

My report on the small schools will be prepared during my visit to Vancouver Island on other duties and forwarded to you during the next two weeks.

At the present time I do not see how any schools now in operation could possibly be closed, if we are to continue the education of the children concerned, for the residential schools are all filled to capacity at present authorized.

Moving children from a small day school where there are for example 12 children on the roll to a residential school would result in an increased expenditure to the Department.

Such a small day school as I have mentioned costs some £1000.00 per annum to operate while the 12 pupils at a residential school would cost in per capita fees alone some £6000.00. The attendance at small Indian day schools in late spring and early Fall would not exceed some 50% and probably not at any time exceed 80% of the number on the roll of the school.

In general the closing of day schools and transferring the pupils to residential schools could not possibly be justified on the ground of expense to the Department. It is in any case impossible from a practical point of view as there are no vacancies at the residential schools, and my efforts to have the numbers entitled to draw per capita allowance at certain of the residential schools, e.g., Mary's Mission for instance, have not so far been very successful.
The possibility of operating some of our Indian schools on an eight month basis has been considered in the past. Schools at Massett, Skidegate, and Gwaiiha are now operating on an eight months basis.

The difficulty is that when schools are open only eight months in a year we cannot, except in unusual circumstances, obtain the services of the better qualified teachers. Such teachers are able to obtain ten month schools under the Provincial Department of Education. It may be possible to suggest that one or two of the small schools be reduced to eight month schools, and this will be discussed in my final report on this subject.

The sending of our children to Provincial schools while satisfactory in places where no Indian school is in operation and numbers are far too small for the establishment of such an Indian school is not the best arrangement for two reasons:

(a) Catholic children can not obtain any religious instruction at Provincial schools.

(b) The Programme of Study in Provincial schools is not the best for Indian children, that is Indian schools being adapted to the child's future.

This matter will however be further reported on in my final survey of these small schools.

With regard to the final paragraph of Mr. Hoey's letter of November 2nd, I am of course well aware that the salaries paid in our Indian schools are in general higher than those paid by the Province in rural schools.

The Province has for some years been trying to find some way to increase the rural salaries. Should we reduce salaries or place many schools on an eight month basis the result will be that qualified teachers will not accept appointments in Indian schools and the standards I have for years attempted to maintain will fail to the very inadequate level noticed when I took up my work in 1941.

There is a very definite shortage of qualified teachers in British Columbia this year. We are so far unable to find teachers for Gitlakdamix (Anglican) Kincolith Division (Anglican) and Massett Division 3 also Anglican. I have consulted Anglican Church authorities, and the registrar of the B.C. Education Department, who is just as unable to find teachers as I am, but have not found suitable candidates.

I would request that you consider this letter an Interim Report on the possibilities suggested in Mr. Hoey's letter of November 2nd.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Sea Bird Island Indian Day School, Roman Catholic Church, Lytton Agency, which was inspected this morning.

The children attending this school are well dressed, and clean. They appear very happy and are certainly making excellent progress.

The teacher, Miss Boeur, has made a very great success of her work here. As the future of this particular school is somewhat doubtful, it is quite possible the teacher may seek a transfer through nomination by the Catholic Church authorities. Her vacation address will be in care of Mrs A. J. Boeur, R.M., Abbotsford, B.C.

Only about 12 of the 16 pupils attend well. Some of the others are, the teacher states, not strong, and some have a distance to walk to school.

The dozen or so children who do attend fairly regularly might possibly be accommodated in the Agassiz Consolidated School, as the school bus passes quite near to their homes, Miss Boeur states. Other pupils could not however be picked up easily.

I am of the opinion that it would be best to operate this school from October 1st to May 31st yearly in the location in which it is now established, the Indian Council House on Sea Bird Island, till such time as the permanent location of the majority of the Indian parents has been decided on, new houses built, etc., when it may be necessary to erect a new school in a more central location.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter dated May 6th regarding the letter from Mrs. Lydia E. Culton, teacher of the Seabird Island Indian School, I beg to report as follows:

I proceeded to Agassiz and went direct to the teacher, requesting the names of the children whom she accused of breaking and entering a house at Agassiz. She gave me the names of Thomas Harris and Benny Joe and although not directly accusing him gave me to understand that Sylvester Joe was also implicated. After listening to her for some time and incidentally so loud did she talk in telling me of drunkenness in and around the reserve, Indians lying on the road and around the church drunk, that the echo from her voice was quite distinct, I left her and proceeded to interview the children reported absent from school.

The first child I visited was Johnny Bobb who lives with his grandparents. On being questioned as to why he did not go to school as he had always been a good boy, never giving any trouble previously, he came right out and said he did not like the teacher's manner, she shouted too much. I told him he must go to school which he promised to do.

I next went to see Sylvester Joe and his parents. This boy is a T.B. case and has not been feeling well enough to go to school; he is one of the children who will go to the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital and it is recognized that he only attends school when feeling well enough. Mrs. Joe and her daughter-in-law were both very much put out with the manner of the teacher, not only with children, but with the people on the reserve generally. I next called on the Pettis children; Margaret, aged 15, was discharged from the Mission School as she was required at home to keep house for her father as her mother is dead. Margaret attended the day school for a short period after her brother married and his wife took over the housework but she is now keeping house for her grandfather, Johnny Bob. Charles Pettis has been kept at home because of a bad cold and also he is another T.B. case and not expected to attend school regularly. Thomas Harris is another case for the new Indian Hospital when it is open. This boy decidedly looks far from well and just wants to lie around all the time. Martin Harris, accused of keeping this boy from school, emphatically denied this and Mary Jane, mother of the boy, when faced with the fact that she signed a statement to this effect said that she told both Father Patterson and the teacher that day that Martin wanted Francis to attend school but the boy was not feeling well enough to do so but the teacher shouted her down and Mary Jane said, "What could I do when they told me to sign my name?". Marion Harris, aged 15, said that...

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
said that she liked school but could not stand the teacher shouting at her and threatens to run away if made to attend school. Marion has reached the age where her fancies are turning to boys and it would be useless now to force her to attend. I met Mollie on the Peters children, Irene and Elsie, who were first kept at home with bad colds and are now having an epidemic of measles all to themselves. As one gets well another goes down; they are under the care of Dr. McCaffrey. The Indians have all the same complaint, that the teacher shouts at them and bosses them too much.

Mrs. Culton does not understand nor ever will understand the temperament of the Indians; they are not used to being shouted at and bullied by officials and as you are aware, Mrs. Culton cannot be told this. To give you an instance of how they take this: On my way to the Reserve I met Fred Even, the blind Indian going to Agassiz which is about 5 miles from his place, to obtain some medicine. I told him that drugs were available from the supply at the school. He said, "Mr. Strang, I'd rather walk to Agassiz and pay for my drugs than go near that woman at the school." Others also complained about her shouting at them when they called for cough medicine, etc.

Following up the alleged breaking and entering by Thomas Harris and the Joe boys of which they denied any knowledge, I called on Constable J.H. Davey of the Provincial Police in Agassiz and he showed me the police record of the case where Charles Thomas and George Douglas had entered a house belonging to a Chinese and taken a watch and other articles later recovered by the police and returned to the owner who refused to prosecute. These two boys have no connection with the school whatsoever. This happened during the month of March and the police report is dated the 14th of that month.

I then brought up the complaint made verbally by the teacher of the wholesale drunkenness on the reserve Saturday nights and Constable Davey informed me that regular patrols were made over Seabird Island, more especially on Saturday nights, and that there was no truth in the statement made by the teacher in this regard, that the Rev. Father Patterson had been talking two days previously about the canoe races to be held on May 24th at Maria Slough and the Father had remarked how well behaved the Indians on Seabird Island had been over a long period.

While visiting at Johnny Bobb's place, Mrs. William Bobb, (nee Marion Phillip), a graduate of the St. George's School, accused the teacher of causing friction among the people and relating stories to Father Patterson about them, mostly information she has gained through gossip.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am returning herewith copy of Mr Indian Agent Strang's report 14-2 dated May 12th last in the matter of Mrs. Lydia Oulton, teacher of the Sea Bird Island Indian Day School.

The above report, as well as a letter from Mrs. A. Andrew dated May 12th and addressed to Mr. Strang, were, as you will remember, handed to me for consideration before any further action was taken with regard to the teacher at Sea Bird Island.

As arranged I visited Sea Bird Island this morning and had a lengthy conference with Mrs. Oulton. This school now operating on an eight months basis, there were no children present as the school closed on May 31st.

Mrs. Oulton was not shown Mr. Stang's report, but the subject matter of that report was discussed with her.

The following is a brief outline of the statements made by the teacher to me. It should be read in connection with Mr. Strang's report of May 12th.

Mrs. Oulton was informed by me that a number of the Indian parents appeared to be very much upset by her actions, shouting at the children, etc.

In reply the teacher informed me that previous to her taking up residence at the school the building had been used at night as a meeting place for unmarried couples. She also stated that the Priest's room at the rear of the Church had also been used for the night by unmarried men and women. Mrs. Oulton's arrival at the school had of course put a stop to such action as is indicated above, and she considers that certain Indians are most anxious to get rid of her, and that these people are making statements to the Indian agent which are not in fact true. Mrs. Oulton admitted to me that she did not have a high regard for Mr. Strang, and that she thought she had not had sufficient co-operation from him.

Mrs. Oulton still believes that there is considerable drinking going on on this Reserve. She sees Indians going to a house near the school where she believes they obtain "liquor". She tells me that she has seen Mrs. Andrew's daughter (?) lying drunk on the road on a Sunday night.
The teacher states that Johnny Bob's niece, who was married to a "white" man who is still alive, is living at John Bob's place. Another "white" man is also living on the Reserve at the same house. This "white" man delivered milk from John Bob's wagon to her, Mrs Culton, at the school one day towards the end of May.

The teacher states that JOHNNY BOBB played truant on two occasions. The grandfather asked the teacher to punish Johnny but Mrs Culton refused. She understands the grandfather did himself strap the boy.

Mrs Culton doubts that SYLVESTER JOE has T.B. and asked me for my authority in making a statement that he did have T.B. The teacher pointed out from the register that Sylvester did not attend school a single day, while Miss Boeur was teacher, during the school year 1939-40. The same boy only missed school on two occasions between October and December 1940, while Mrs Culton was teacher. Sylvester missed school on six days during the January-March quarter 1941, and has not been to school since the beginning of April of this year.

The case of MARGARET PETTIS was discussed with the teacher and it was pointed out to her that the above girl was discharged from St. Mary's School Mission with the permission of the Department, that she was wanted at home, and that being 15 years of age we did not insist on her going to school. I explained to Mrs Culton that in B.C. children reaching their 16th birthday were not forced to attend Provincial schools and that we followed much the same course except in certain special cases.

CHARLES PETTIS has, the teacher states, been playing truant with Johnny Bobb. She quotes Johnny's grandfather and Mrs D. Charles his aunt as making this statement to her.

THOMAS HARRIS runs around and plays ball on Sunday with the others. The teacher states that Thomas helps his grandfather, Martin Harris. Thomas tells the teacher that Martin Harris will not let him go to school.

MARRION HARRIS has never been near the school since Mrs Culton was appointed teacher. The teacher has never even spoken to her. Marion was only at school for thirteen days during the school year 1939-40 when Miss Boeur was teacher.

Mrs Culton had not heard that the PETTIS children were ill with measles. She sees these children around with the other children, and were at the games etc. on the 24th of May.

Mrs Culton states that the case of Fred Culton is bound up with a dispute about the purchase of wood for fuel at the end of last year. The Indian Agent left it to the teacher to arrange the purchase and she did not know that Fred Ewen should be given the contract.

I explained to Mrs Culton that in the case of breaking and entering in Agassiz the Joe boys and Thomas Harris had nothing whatever to do with the matter. She had listened to Indians talking about this and I am convinced mixed up names. I did not inform Mrs Culton of the information given by Mr Strang in reference to this particular case, but just told her that she was mistaken, but that I could understand that names had been mixed up in the conversation overheard.
While I consider that Mr Strang's report of May 12th does not disclose all the facts in each case, I do agree with him that Mrs Oulton does not understand the temperament of Indians. I am satisfied that she shouts at the Indians, including the children, and that she is a most difficult person to reason with.

My own opinion is that the Sea Bird Island Indians are playing with Mrs Oulton and with Mr Strang, and for their own reasons trying to make further trouble between Mrs Oulton and Mr Strang. It is reasonably clear that a section of these Indians do want to get rid of the teacher, as does Mr Strang from his own official correspondence.

When a teacher is unable to get along well with her Indian Agent and with the Indians I believe that it is time to take the teacher out of that school. It is very obvious that Mrs Oulton's usefulness to the Department in her present position has been considerably impaired of late.

Mrs Oulton's professional work has been reported on twice during the past academic year. Please see my reports of October 26th 1940 and of April 15th 1941, on the Sea Bird Island Indian Day School. Mrs Oulton is not in any way an outstanding teacher, but she has worked hard to improve the standing of her Grades. She did increase the attendance during the year.

I have suggested to Mrs Oulton that she make official application through her Indian Agent for a transfer to another school in B.C. for the next academic year. I also suggested that she write to His Excellency Archbishop Duke to ask him to consider her when making nominations to fill vacancies.

Mrs Oulton did not wish to leave Sea Bird Island but tells me that she will follow my advice and ask for a transfer. I think that it may be possible to arrange this later, but the fact that she has a little girl now going into Grade 6 will have to be taken into account. Mother and child were as you know left to look after themselves by the father who does not contribute, I am informed, to their support.

I trust that the solution to this troublesome matter indicated above will be satisfactory to you, and I may say that I intend to inform Rev Father Patterson, O.M.I., if I can see him at Mission tomorrow of the suggestion made to Mrs Oulton and of the reasons for her transfer. He is the Catholic Missionary of the district.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter 14-2 of the 12th instant with which you forward Mrs. L. L. Oulton's request for a transfer.

If a suitable school can be found for Mrs. Oulton, her transfer to such school will be recommended to the Department.

In accordance with your request I enquired into

28th, 1942 forwarding the petition of Chief Harry Joseph,
of Seabird Island Reserve, dated December 10th, 1941.

I met the Chief and his Secretary, Edward J. Peters,
on the 13th instant and endeavoured to ascertain their
complaints against Mrs. Culton, but could secure nothing
of a very specific nature. They complained in a vague and
general way that Mrs. Culton interfered in Indian matters
on the Reserve that did not concern her and thus trespassed
on the Chief's sphere of activity. Also that Mrs. Harry
David complained that she was too rough with her children.
It is clear that Mrs. Culton is disliked by them.

I understood from Mr. Strang that Dr. McCaffery
refused to have any dealings with her and I interviewed
him on the subject, but his attitude was that he had no
definite complaint to make but did not like the woman and
consequently left her alone as much as possible.

from their slats and they were not very orderly. I in-
structed the Agent to see that they were replaced on new
