Dear Sir:

Re: Teacher, Seabird Island Indian Day School

I beg to enclose herewith a letter signed by the Chief, Harry Joseph, and the Secretary, Ed. J. Peters, of the Seabird Island Band Councillors with respect to the Teacher of their Indian Day School.

Although I have had various complaints prior to this petition, from Whites as well as Indians, regarding Mrs. Culton's adverse activities in connection with the administration of this Agency, this petition was withheld until I could visit the School and the Reserve.

On the occasion of my visit to the Seabird Island School during this month, I must say that the teacher, Mrs. Culton, treated my visit with the utmost disrespect in front of the children. I interviewed several of the Indians, including the Chief, and find that she has been counselling them not to write their Agent for anything, but to communicate with Ottawa or the Commissioner's office. I talked with Dr. P. S. McCaffrey, Medical Health Officer for the Indians, regarding the situation and he simply informed me that he did not feel like visiting the School, owing to the Teacher's manner.

I do not question her teaching abilities but she is living in the small quarters attached to the council house, kindly loaned to the Department for school purposes by the Band, and the building is not kept as clean as it might be and not nearly as clean as it was kept by previous teachers. The Indians are deprived altogether of the use of this building which they especially require on Sundays during the winter months, as most of them come long distances to attend church and require the building to prepare and eat their lunches.

The Teacher does not recognize the Chief and has created a decided division among the members of the Band.

I have endeavored in every way to co-operate with Mrs. Culton but she will not be advised and I find that she is a detriment to the welfare of the Indians and I therefore recommend that the Department dispense with her services as a Teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Major D. M. MacKay,

I wish to refer to your letter of October 21, 1946, and previous correspondence regarding Mrs. Lydia L. Culton, employed as teacher at the Seabird Island Indian Day School, Lytton Agency.

The Department is aware that Mr. Indian Agent Strang on various occasions in recent years requested the removal of Mrs. Culton from the school on the grounds that she interfered in matters on the Reserve outside her province as teacher and also that she failed to extend to him the cooperation necessary in the best interests of the operation of the school and his administration of the Indians of the Reserve. A perusal of Inspection Reports on this teacher indicates that her work in the classroom could be regarded as fair and it is altogether likely that had she been content to confine her activities to her duties as teacher she would have been able to get along much better with the Indians and Mr. Indian Agent Strang.

The situation at Seabird Island has been the subject of discussion with Archbishop Duke since early last year with a view to finding a satisfactory solution, but in the absence of a suitable transfer the alternative was to close the school, a move that did not appear desirable. In conversation regarding this matter with Archbishop Duke a few days ago, I suggested to him that Mrs. Culton be transferred to Homalco Indian Day School which has become
vacant as a result of the transfer of Mr. Grist to Pemberton, and His Excellency agreed to this arrangement. Having this in mind I went out to Seabird Island yesterday and informed Mrs. Culton that the Department could not permit the existing situation at the school to continue and that a change must be made. At the same time she was advised of the vacancy at Church House and agreed to accept the transfer to our school at that point. I would therefore recommend that her transfer from Seabird Island to Komalco be approved and that her salary at Komalco be the same as that paid to Mr. Grist while he held the position as teacher at that place. The Department's decision by air mail at an early date in regard to this matter would be appreciated.

D. N. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sirs:

In your letter of July 26 (File No. 845-177) you have pointed out to me the difficulty of claiming the Income Tax Deduction on an overpayment of salary to myself. The method you suggested for straightening out this matter is not suitable to me for many good reasons.

As yet there are several debts incurred from a long period of illness and unemployment which have the highest priority claim on my present salary. Also the method the Government has chosen to claim its income taxes and the other rules and regulations pertaining to it. Since the amount is large enough for me to think about I might point out that if in the eventuality of my sudden demise (such things occurring at any time to the least expectant) the money would be returned then I would have lost the benefit of its good use (the matter of my estate being already attended to).

Surely a more amicable solution to this problem will be found. Please understand that I will try to assist you in anyway that does not necessitate my making cash payments for the settlement of this account. Please note the change of address.

Yours Truly,

Ottawa, September 9, 1924.

Sir:

I beg to inform you that Mr. H. H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of British Columbia, has informed the Department of the resignation of Mrs. F. Appel (nee Edith Delaney) as teacher of the Seabird Island Indian Day School, and has, on the recommendation of Rev. Father Welch, O.M.I., nominated the services of Mrs. Carpenter to take charge from the 1st of October, next. The Department is approving of the temporary appointment of Mrs. Carpenter, her retention in the position to depend upon the success which she achieves in the work. She has no certificate as a teacher, but was trained in England, where she had some experience as a pupil-teacher. The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $700 per annum, supplemented by the bonus provided by law. Payment of both salary and bonus is based on ten teaching months in the year.

I shall be pleased if you will give Mrs. Carpenter any assistance you can in her work at this school.

FORM 14
Ottawa, March 8th, 1926.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Cairns, in a report on his inspection of the Seabird Island Indian Day School, states that the Indian parents are taking more interest in the education of their children and have expressed a desire to have a change of teacher. As you were advised at the time of the appointment of Mrs. Carpenter, the present teacher, her retention in the position was to depend upon the success which she achieved in the work. It appears from reports received that her services have not been entirely satisfactory, and it is desired that a qualified teacher be engaged for the next school year. You should inform Mrs. Carpenter in due time that her services will not be required after the end of the present school year, viz., June 30th, next.

As this school is conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church authorities, it will be necessary to consult them regarding the appointment of a successor to Mrs. Carpenter. You should take this matter up with the Church authorities in due time, and also with Mr. Inspector Cairns, and submit the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated for the position. You will please keep this matter in mind and make all necessary arrangements, as requested above, in due time to have a suitable teacher engaged for the next school year.

We are informing Mr. Inspector Cairns that you have been instructed to notify Mrs. Carpenter that her services will not be required after the end of June, next, and to take the necessary action to obtain the services of a successor.

Your obedient servant,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Dear Sir:

Your File 165-5-5.

The attached voucher covers labour in carrying out certain repairs to the Seabird Island Indian Day School. It was intended that the labour would be provided by the Indians without cost to the Department, but the teacher, Mrs. L. E. Oulton, employed a local white carpenter without authority from the Agent or this office. The teacher's reasons for this are that the Indians were not available to do the work at the time and as the weather was wet and stormy, such action was necessary. Mrs. Oulton has been advised that in future she must secure the requisite authority before incurring expenditures involving the Department.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. MacKay.
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
SURVEYS and ENGINEERING BRANCH

Scotbird Island Indian Day School -

As you are aware, a sum of $8,000.00 has been included in our 1947-48 estimates for the construction of a one-room day school and teachersage at the Scotbird Island Reserve in the Lytton Agency. We have written recently to Indian Commissioner MacKay, Vancouver, B.C., concerning this new construction asking him about the local building situation. He has answered in part as follows:

"Mr. William Swan, Hatzic, B.C., would undertake the work on a daily basis. Mr. Swan is a well known and reliable contractor and builder and has done good work for us at both the Kamloops and St. Mary's Residential Schools."

He has also requested that your branch undertake the supervision and responsibility for the construction of this building.

Therefore it will be in order for you to advertise for tenders for the construction of a standard one-room school at this point.

Director,

Seabird Island Community area showing proposed school site. Photo taken from Provincial Government bridge over Maria Slough. Photo taken at approximate bearing of N.30°E astronomical.

Seabird Island Community area taken from a point some 50 feet from proposed school site. Photo taken at approximate astronomical bearing of S50°W in a direction toward the bridge over Maria Slough.
Re: Seabird Island School, Lytton Agency

As requested, I visited Seabird Island together with Mr. Davey, Inspector of Indian Schools and Mr. Strang, Indian Agent, Lytton Agency, on May 12, 1947, to determine a suitable site for a single room school with teacher quarters.

Seabird Island

Seabird Island is a delta island about 5 miles long and 1½ miles wide located in the Fraser Valley, 1½ miles north east of Agassiz. The island, which is approximately 70 ft. above mean sea level, is covered with a heavy growth of birch, poplar, alder and willow, and some fir and cedar. Patches of land varying from 2 acres to 35 acres have been cleared and farmed by Indians. These farmed areas are on the south western two-thirds of the Island. The area is higher than most delta islands of the Fraser, and does not require dikes or pumping equipment.

School Site

The area considered to be most convenient was a level area near the south west end of the island where the provincial government road crosses the island. At this point there has been established a church, small community hall and recreation facilities. See "A" and also photographs, Appendix II. The school site is adjacent to and north east of the playground. Diagram "B" is a rough sketch of suggested position of school buildings and domestic facilities. It also gives an indication of river condition. On May 12, 1947 river levels were at ground level at proposed site. The elevation of the site does not vary by more than one foot.
Nature of soil Drainage

Referring to Sketch "B", the playground, church and community hall surface soil is of a clay and even grained fine sand which appears to drain fairly well. The site chosen for the school is about 6" higher than the playfield and the surface soil is of even medium sized grain sand. The sand is not very firm and would require spread footings. Three feet below the surface this sand changes to a 1" gravel mixed with sand. The gravel is reasonably firm and suitable for footings.

The water table of the site (which is true of the whole island) rises and falls according to the level of the Fraser River. The water table can be considered to be equal to the height of the river, except in winter when it is probably two feet higher. The Fraser generally reaches its highest level in June and at that time is probably some 6 feet above the winter level. Therefore, the highest water table occurs in June and may remain at a high level for one month.

Levels of the river, school site and road bridge gap are shown on sketch "B". Fraser River levels are recorded at Hope, Chilliwack and Mission. Estimated river heights at Maria Slough adjacent to the school site have been determined from these records and incorporated into sketch "B" showing probable water table levels.

Agricultural drain tiles could be used to drain away roof and surface to the river but would not be effective under maximum Fraser flood conditions. However, at this time the rainfall is fairly light. If at any time water closets were established in the school, a septic tank properly constructed would work effectively.
Water Supply

A small stream of about 1 gal. per minute flows down a steep mountain to the west of the island and the school site. It is said this stream does not dry up. A possible point of tapping this stream is some 200 feet from its mouth. This would require a pipe line 1400 feet long - 300 feet over land plus 600 feet over Maria Slough, from the proposed school.

Water also may be obtained from a well located anywhere on the school area. Such a well would have to be some 16 feet deep. This well is recommended at this time. Chemical tests on water taken from a well 1 mile away showed such water to be very satisfactory for domestic purposes. See Appendix I.

Electricity

Agassiz some 4 miles from the school site is served with electricity from the B.C. Company. As there are few possible customers in the direction toward and past the school, the B.C. Company consider it will be some time before lines will be extended into this area.

Climate

Climate conditions are as recorded at Agassiz, namely:

Sunlight - 1422 hours
Rainfall - 62 inches
Average winter temperatures - December 37°, January 35°, and February 38°.

Extreme temperature usually in January and seldom lower than 0°. This temperature may occur once in five years. Prevailing winter wind is from the east.

River Levels

Extreme high water levels such as that of 1894 apparently occur rarely. The 1894 flood was the highest in the period of record, 1875 to date, on the Thompson River. (RG 10, volume 6410, file 840-5, part 1)
Fraser and 1856 to date on the Columbia. It reached a gauge height of 25.75 feet on the Fraser at Mission. Flood waters about 20.0 feet on the Mission gauge apparently occur about once every five years. This level is considered the danger point for most diked areas in the whole Fraser Valley.

Recommendation

The school basement floor should not be below a level corresponding to 20 feet on the Mission gauge. A suggested level of 2.0 feet below the top of the bridge cap for the top of the basement floor should result in its being free of flood waters, except those of the magnitude of that which occurred in 1894. It is estimated that this level would correspond to a level of 23 feet at the Mission gauge.

Mosquitoes are very prevalent in this area during the early summer season and it is considered all windows which may be opened should be provided with screens.

Fuel available is wood, coal or oil. Sawdust might be available, but assured supply is doubtful. It is recommended coal fuel be used.

Re: Day School, Seabird Island I.N. #1,

With reference to Mr. Hoey's memorandum of April 11th last and your notation thereon dated April 15th, 1947, we have recently received from Mr. C.E. Webb, Vancouver, a report with plans prepared by Mr. Unsworth of his staff, relating to the site of the above named school.

We are forwarding to you herewith for the information and records of the Indian Affairs Branch two copies of each of the following:

(a) extract from Mr. Unsworth's report,
(b) appendices I and II to the report,
(c) Plan (A) of Seabird Island and Plan (B) of the proposed school site.

It will be noted from the report that the site was selected by Mr. Davy, Inspector of Indian Schools, Indian Agent Strang and Mr. Unsworth as being the best suitable and convenient for the erection of the school.

From the data furnished we would recommend that the basement floor be laid at a level of 2'-2" below the present ground level at the site, and that the earth be raised up (terraced) around the building to an elevation of 2'-4" above the ground level for a distance of about 15 feet around the building. This would ensure the building resting upon a solid sand and gravel sub-ball, the basement floor and the concrete footings being above the height of flood waters (excepting that recorded in 1894) and the possibility of drainage by gravity flow of water from the roofs, basement floor and foundation drains to Maria Slough—a distance of approximately 450 feet.

Such drainage line is not, of course, included in the Trade Specifications covering the standard building with which the Indian Affairs Branch has been furnished.

Regarding the water supply, it is recommended that a well about 16 feet deep be sunk at a point clear of the terracing approximately where shown on site Plan B. It will be noted that chemical tests show water taken from a well 1 mile away to be pure for drinking purposes.

Seabird Island Indian Day School

We have now received a complete report from the Surveys and Engineering Branch concerning the proposed building site for the day school at this reserve. You will be able to obtain from Mr. Unsworth, who submitted this report, the complete details thereon. However, pertinent extracts as we have received them are as follows:

"From the data furnished we would recommend that the basement floor be laid at a level of 2'-2" below the present ground level at the site, and that the earth be graded up (terraced) around the building to an elevation of 2'-4" above the ground level for a distance of about 15 feet around the building. This would ensure the building resting upon a solid sand and gravel sub-soil, the basement floor and the concrete footings being above the height of flood waters (excepting that recorded in 1894) and the possibility of drainage by gravity flow of water from the roofs, basement floor and foundation drains to Maria Slough - a distance of approximately 450 feet.

"Such drainage line is not, of course, included in the Trade Specifications covering the standard building with which the Indian Affairs Branch has been furnished.

"Regarding the water supply, it is recommended that a well about 16 feet deep be sunk at a point clear of the terracing approximately where shown on site Plan B. It will be noted that chemical tests show water taken from a well 1 mile away to be pure for drinking purposes."
"No service piping into the building is included in the Plumbing Specification and it is assumed that Indian Affairs will install a cover with hand pump above the wall.

"Fly screens also are not included in our Standard Specification for this school, but since mosquitoes are prevalent in the District, screens 1-1/8 inch thick with 14 x 14 galvanized cloth mesh should be made and fitted into all opening windows at the school. It should be noted also that storm sash which are included in our specification for this type of school will not be required at Seabird Island."

Therefore, it will be in order for you now to approach Mr. Swan at Hatzic and any other contractors whom it is felt would be willing to undertake the construction of this school.

The following changes in the specifications will be permitted,-

(1) The elimination of the storm sashes and the substitution of fly screens for them.

(2) If asphalt shingles are in short supply in your vicinity, we will authorize the use of insul-brick siding in its place.

We will expect to hear from you in the near future concerning the digging of the well recommended by Surveys and Engineering Branch and also with estimates from Mr. Swan and such other contractors who are interested. Immediately this latter information is obtained, we will request an Order in Council authorizing the construction of this school.

Ottawa, March 2, 1948.

Mr. A. Strang, Indian Agent, Lytton, British Columbia.

Seabird Island Indian Day School.

Reference your 1h-2-165 of February 23.

Your recommendation with regard to the well being dug in the basement has been noted. Unless you are assured of a steady source of water, it might be preferable to have the well dug outside the school building so that it can be easily cleaned out and will not become foul over the years.

We have had some difficulty with the pressure tank and small gasoline engines in other schools. This has been due to the fact that many teachers do not understand the operation of these gasoline engines and the Indian Agent has been plagued with minor repairs and adjustments, etc., to the engines. Therefore, we have been using hand operated pressure tanks with some success.

This would mean that the well would be just outside the school building and connected to the pressure tank in the basement by a pipe at least six feet underground. This pressure tank would be hand operated and the teacher would have to maintain the pressure once or twice a day in order that the pump would operate into the kitchen sink.
Further to our letter of January 30th, we have had several discussions with Inspector Ostrander of Saskatchewan. He has reported that Contractors are not particularly interested there in accepting a flat contract for the construction of this school. It is not his intention to recommend advertising but he is instead proceeding with the construction of these schools on a day labour basis.

We have, therefore, submitted two types of day labour tenders:

(a) For a foreman carpenter at a wage varying from $1.25 to $1.50 an hour.

(b) For a flat labour tender on the school (usually about $4,000.00).

In either of the above instances, the Department provides the materials as per the standard bill of materials which we have prepared. Could you please advise me whether there are any Contractors interested in the above proposals. If so, we can proceed to order the materials immediately for delivery in May and June. This would eliminate the necessity of advertising for Contractors.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: Seabird Island Indian Day School

Forwarded the Department herewith is a copy of a letter received this date from the Archbishop of Vancouver, in which he requests that inside plumbing facilities for the teacher and the pupils be installed in the above new school now under construction.

It is my impression that the plan of the school would not permit such an installation on the main floor but in view of the fact that an adequate water supply may be obtained by the installation of an automatic pump in the present well I would respectfully recommend that an addition be made to the building for the accommodation of plumbing.

As pointed out, the installation of the above would prove a good practical lesson to the Indians residing on the Reserve and would also prove very satisfactory from a stand point of health.

Dear Mr. Strang:

I was at Seabird Island for the confirmation of the children and was much pleased to see the new school now under construction on that Reserve.

I would like to offer you my sincere congratulations for obtaining this school for the little children of that important area which is so loved by the Indian people.

What struck me was, however, that there should be inside plumbing both for the teacher and for the children. This would mean so much for the health of all concerned, and besides, add a practical lesson in what ought to obtain now in this Province in all homes.

I am sure you realize why I write these few lines and if I can help to get this from the Department I would very gladly do whatever I can.

In the new school to be built at Anaham this year we are asking the same favor of the Department, and it means so much for so many for so little.

With kind regards, I remain

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Re: our requisition dated April 9th, 1948 - materials for Seabird Island Indian Day School.

Attached is quotation received from Valleyumber Yards Limited. I presume it should have been forwarded to you.

We have just received a letter from Indian Commissioner Arnell which reads in part as follows:

"I may say, however, that as a result of flood conditions prevailing at the present time, Seabird Island Reserve is under water and until the flood recedes and a survey of the situation is made, no further action with respect to construction of this school should be taken."

In order that there may be no unnecessary delay it would appear advisable to proceed with the purchase of the materials but the firms to whom the business is awarded should be very definitely informed that no deliveries are to be made until they are advised to do so.

Bernard P. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MGD

Re: Seabird Island Indian Day School
Your file 165-5-5 (E)

With reference to Mr. Neary's Army Signals message of May 26th, we have been successful in securing the necessary reinforcing mesh and reinforcing rods for the new Seabird Island Indian Day School at an approximate cost of $120, f.o.b. Vancouver, and in addition have secured a tender on lumber from the Valley Lumber Yards which are forwarded herewith in duplicate.

I may say, however, that as a result of flood conditions prevailing at the present time Seabird Island Reserve is under water and until the flood recedes and a survey of the situation is made no further action with respect to construction of this school should be taken. Mr. Strong is receiving a copy of this letter and will no doubt communicate with you at a later date.

W.S. Arneil,

Re: Seabird Island School, 165-5-5 (E)

I have to refer to Mr. Henry's Army Signals message of October 13th authorizing local purchase of windows and frames, etc., for the new Seabird Island School.

Orders have been placed for most of the items referred to except from the window frames and other millwork which are covered by the attached quotation from Sigurdson Millwork Ltd. You will note that delivery is from four to six weeks, the reason being that windows, casings, doors, etc., do not conform with standard sizes commonly used in British Columbia. These items consequently must be made to order with considerable delay and higher costs. This is a point which I have for some time been considering bringing to your attention. The Department's standard school plans, while no doubt conforming with standard construction practice in eastern Canada do not conform with standard practice here nor does the sash, millwork, etc., conform with standard size here.

I would suggest that construction costs could be reduced and construction expedited if arrangements were made for a revision of the Department's standard school plans for use in British Columbia. I can arrange this and submit amended plans and specifications for your approval if you so desire and in the meantime as far as the Seabird Island school is concerned I would suggest that an order be placed with Sigurdson Millwork Co. Ltd., in accordance with their quotation. There may be some minor duplications of items previously ordered from the Valley Lumber Yards.
Limited, but to arrange for deletion of these minor items from Sigurdson's quotation would entail considerable delay and as it took over three weeks to secure the quotation we do not wish to delay the matter further.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Seabird Island Indian Day School
Your file 840-5 (E)

With reference to Supt. Strang's letter of November 24th attached and Progress Payment No. 3 in favour of Messrs. Laughington and Reynold, Mr. Strang and Mr. Reynolds called at this office recently and discussed with me the contract covering the erection of the Seabird Island school, and at the same time arrangements were made to secure the additional materials required for completion of the building.

The contractor's request for a progress payment at this time is not considered to be unreasonable inasmuch as had the necessary materials been made available to him as required the school would likely have been completed before this. I might mention that this office was under the impression, reference Mr. Neary's letter of April 15th to Supt. Strang and his reply thereto, that the Departmental Purchasing Agent had arranged for the supply of all necessary materials and it was only on receipt of your various Signals messages requesting us to secure materials that we realized that the matter had not been attended to. The exterior work completed by the contractor at this time is the equivalent or more of the interior work required by Progress Payment No. 3 and I feel that the payment should be made at this time.

W. S. Arneil,

Re: Seabird Island Indian Day School

With reference to our exchange of army signal messages regarding the heating installation at the above mentioned school, the contract with Messrs. Laughington and Reynolds was entered into without reference to this office and we do not have a copy on file. Mr. Neary's message indicates, however, that in the absence of any reference to the contrary, the contractor's tender should include the provision of labour for the installation of the furnace, piping, etc., which should be supplied by the department.

The former Superintendent, Mr. Strang, and Mr. McGregor, who is presently acting as Superintendent at Lytton, are of the opinion that in as much as the contractors were unnecessarily delayed by our failure to make materials available when required with the result that they have lost money on the contract, the department should meet the cost of installing the heating system.

The attached tenders as listed below cover supply of the necessary materials and installation of the heating system, and you will note that each Company was requested to tender separately on material and labour so that if the department insisted on the installation being made by the general contractors, a separate order for materials could be readily placed.

Material $447.00

Sir,

I beg to report the position I am in in regard to the proposed and also the existing schools in this Agency.

Yesterday I visited the Shalalth School, which is on the Seton Lake Reserve, and which is a joint Provincial and Indian Department school, and under the circumstances the teacher is supplied by the Provincial Government.

This school I am glad to report is progressing excellently, the children are making splendid headway and the parents are very well satisfied. The priest visited the reserve recently and told the Indians that they were to insist upon a Roman Catholic teacher, otherwise they were not to send their children. Naturally they were very concerned about this, and sent for me. I explained the whole thing to them and told them that we had no jurisdiction over the teacher, as she was appointed by the Provincial Government, and furthermore, as no religion was taught in the school, it would not make any difference anyway. My explanation apparently satisfied them for the time being. How long it will last remains to be seen.

Now in regard to the proposed schools for the Hope and Seabird Island Bands, I have applied to Father Welch for a Roman Catholic teacher for each of these, but can get no satisfaction from him. I beg to acknowledge receipt of departmental letter of March 9th, together with a copy of one from Mrs. J. Nebagilati, in regard to the Shalalth School.

The correspondence we had in regard to this school you are acquainted with.

When this school was first thought about Mrs. Nebagilati took the matter up with me with a view of getting a joint school started, as she had two children there who needed education, and there were three other wives. She asked me if I could get the Indian Department to join in as was done, and everything went along smoothly until the end of last year. For a very considerable time there were only the two white children attending, viz: Mrs. Nebagilati's, when the Provincial Government advised me that they had decided that they could not carry it on for only two children, and this is what I reported to you.

What Mrs. Nebagilati says about the building is quite true. She was so anxious to get the school started that she was quite willing, if the Indians would cut the logs and erect the building, to supply the other material, such as doors, shingles, windows, etc., which she did, hoping to get assistance from the other white man who had three children, but it was not long before these two parties were not on speaking terms, with the result that Mrs. Nebagilati had to bear the whole cost. I am not in a position to say what she did pay for the different articles supplied, but think that she is entitled to some compensation, if the Indian Department intend to carry this school on solely as an Indian School.

In regard to the teacher, I might add that Mrs. Nebagilati has not been living in the vicinity for some time as she was in Vancouver running a boardinghouse, and as you know Mrs. Burroughs just offered to carry the school on as a stopgap, which I recommended to the Department in order that the school might not be closed. The whole trouble is that Mrs. Nebagilati and Mrs. Burroughs are not on speaking terms, and she resents Mrs. Burroughs teaching and earning the sum of $150.00 a month. Mrs. Nebagilati came to see me, and asked to see the correspondence, then apparently went away quite satisfied. I am very much afraid that it is just a storm in a teacup for it would be quite impossible for Mrs. Nebagilati to teach the school, and I am of course of opinion, but I do think that Mrs. Nebagilati would be entitled to some compensation for the money she expended in fitting up the school. I might say the school under Mrs. Burroughs is doing very well at present.

Trusting that this explains the whole matter,

Sir,

In reply to departmental letter dated September 1st, in connection with the claim made by Mrs. Nebaglatti for reimbursement for an outlay that she made in the erection of the building now used for a school at Shalalth on Seton Lake I.R.

I wish to say if you will refer to her letter addressed to you and dated February 26th, you will see that she admits that she took the matter up with me, with a view of getting a joint school. This was done, as with the consent of the Indian Department and the Provincial Education Department the school was opened as a joint school.

According to the Provincial Education Department's regulations, the parties applying for one of these schools have to provide the building. This the Indians and Mrs. Nebaglatti agreed to do, and supplied one. The Indians supplied the logs, and built the building, and Mrs. Nebaglatti the lumber, door, window sash, etc., but she could not have spent the sum of $150.00 on this, which she claims she did.

Mr. Inspector Cairns and myself went into this matter very carefully yesterday, and came to the conclusion that Mrs. Nebaglatti only spent the money that she had to, in order to get the school started, and she had her two children educated in it whilst it was being run jointly by the Provincial government and the Indian Department. When the Provincial Department decided to withdraw their grant, and I applied to the Indian Department to keep it open on behalf of the Indians, Mrs. Nebaglatti took one child out, but the other one has remained on, and is still attending. This child, of course, has been attending just through the goodwill of the teacher.

Taking everything into consideration, Mr. Cairns and myself came to the conclusion that Mrs. Nebaglatti has had her money's worth out of the building in the line of having her children educated, and as Mr. Finnigan, the present teacher, states that he has no objection to this child remaining on, we consider that Mrs. Nebaglatti has been well repaid, and that there is nothing due her.

I might add though that there is a table and a chair belonging to Mrs. Nebaglatti, that the Department might purchase. The stove, which she put in there, was an old one, and is now completely worn out. This will have to be replaced. The door also, which was provided by Mrs. Nebaglatti, was secondhand, and will also have to be replaced, as it will be absolutely useless for another wintertime.

Assist. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Progress during the quarter has been very good as was attendance if we take into consideration that a portion of the winter was very severe and quite a depth of snow.

Dear Sir;

I have the honour to forward herewith my report on the Shalalth Indian Day School (Seton Lake) in the Lytton Agency.

I regret that I have to recommend that the services of the present teacher, Mr. Joseph R. Kiernan be dispensed with as from the end of the present school year.

I have on my file of applicants a teacher who is a Roman Catholic, holds a First Class Certificate for Alberta, has twenty years experience, is at present employed as teacher of the Fort Babine Indian Day School, and whose wife is a registered trained nurse. I should like to have this teacher—Mr. C.J. Daly—at the Shalalth Indian Day School, should he be appointed to this position, I believe that the services of his wife as a Field Matron would be of the greatest possible advantage to the Indians on the adjacent Reserves.

Mr. C.J. Daly's address is Indian Day School, Fort Babine, Topley, B.C.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Gerald H. Barry,
District Inspector of Indian Schools.
Joseph P. Kieran. Age 61. No qualifications; experience three and a half years in this school.

Mr. Kieran, in my opinion, knows nothing whatever about teaching. As far as educational work is concerned, the school is in a deplorable condition.

I have given the teacher a list of texts and work books which should be in the school. I have taught a number of "Demonstration Lessons" to indicate method in Number Work and Reading. I believe fact that this was wasted time, as the teacher is too old to benefit by the observation of the above lessons. I asked the teacher not to beat any of the children whom he had been doing. I do not consider it a good plan to carry a stick around in one's hand, as this teacher was doing when I reached the school. This man is quite unfit to exercise the functions of a teacher in my opinion.

The teacher walks around with a stick in his hand and shouts at the children. The discipline is weak. The teacher appears to have no idea that teaching is a scientific profession. He has no knowledge of method. Please see special recommendation attached to this report.

I do not believe that the services of Mr. Joseph P. Kieran are satisfactory. I consider that, for the sake of the children at Shalalth, a change should be made at the end of the present school year.

Though Mr. Kieran has now been the teacher of this school for over three years, the progress of the children is very unsatisfactory. He shows no signs of any training in teaching, being quite ignorant of method. He is not the type of man that should ever have been selected as a teacher for young Indian children. His personality and manner are in themselves enough to make a change in my opinion absolutely necessary.

I, of course, regret the necessity of this recommendation, but if I am to do my duty, no other course is open to me.

Mr. Indian Agent Strang was with me throughout my inspection of the school. I understand that he will also make a similar report to the Department of Indian Affairs. It was at his special request that I visited the Shalalth School at this time.

Strang, the present Indian Agent of the Lytton Reserve that after the present Summer holidays my services are no longer required; no reason being given. This day I am writing Mr. A. Strang requesting the reason; a copy of my letter to him being herewith enclosed. Under separate cover for your perusal I am forwarding as specimens of my efforts a number of copy books of the children.
In case this matter shall not have yet come to your particular attention, this letter is being written and I request that you have an enquiry made and advise me of the reasons for this drastic action.

Thanking you in anticipation of prompt consideration,

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

Joseph P. Kieran

Dear Sirs:

Re: Shalalath Indian School
LYTTON RESERVE, B.C.

By reason of the shortness of time that remains before the reopening of school in September next, and of the distance between here and Ottawa I am writing you at more length concerning my recent dismissal as teacher at the above mentioned Indian School with the hope that I shall be reinstated so as to carry on at the commencement of the school term.

My dismissal does not seem warranted. I wish to direct your attention to the instructions given me by the late Mr. Cairnes, the then inspector and by whom I was appointed; these you will find under the heading of Remarks in my first Annual Report dated 31st March 1928; namely, to teach the children, Reading, Writing and Arithmetic, and a little Geography, the map of Canada. Although, in the said Remarks in my said report I think I did not refer to writing, Mr. Cairnes very distinctly
told me that I could use my own judgment as regards the McLean system. In this regard I would ask you to look over the copy books that I sent you or to have them inspected by some of the Inspectors of Schools in your department who are experienced. You will note that I write the headlines and how I assist the children in this one matter.

During the whole three and a half years of my employment I have never missed a minute away from the school; I have done many things for the children outside the curriculum; giving them candies every week; frequently bread and butter for their lunch when they hadn't any. I have kept their shoes in repair at no cost to them and at Christmas time I gave them clothes and shoes I got from Vancouver friends apart from and irrespective of the grant from the department.

Apparently, Mr. Gerald Barry, your new inspector, came to the school on the 15th of June last with his mind made up to have me fired and so to make as bad a report as he could. I have been informed since, that before coming to the school he had lunch with Mr. Jones, Manager at Bridge River of the British Columbia Electric Company and that when in conversing, Mr. Jones praised my system of education, Mr. Barry was not well pleased and made remarks to Mr. Jones to the effect that I was
Mr. Barry's appearance when he came into the school, and his subsequent, gruff, dictatorial and seemingly insulting manner bore out his predetermination. He spent about an hour and a half in the school, an hour of which he devoted to showing the children all he knew, and the remaining time asking questions. He would not look at the exercise books. The children were intimidated, and he insisted in talking to an eleven year old girl who had been only a couple of weeks at school and who can speak only very little English. He was very impressive in expressing that it was wrong to say "2 and 1 is 3" that such should be "2 plus 1 is 3"; and that "4 from 5 and 1 remains" is also wrong but that it should be "5 take 4 away and 1 is left". He found fault with the children counting on their fingers; said it should be done with matches. But, children have fingers when they haven't matches. Etc.

I have no doubt that if some one else, a man experienced in such matters, were sent to examine this school and without preconceived ideas, my Indian children will compare very favourably with the children of any other school—white or red—.
I think I am entitled to better consideration. Certainly, it does not seem just that I should be dismissed apparently for carrying out the instructions received from the former inspector, the late Mr. Cairnes.

I am most anxious to continue as teacher at Shalalath School; as well, it is most disastrous in these times for me, a man of sixty-two years, to be so relieved of my only employment and source of sustenance.

Be good enough to give this matter your present attention so that I may carry on in September.

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

(Joseph P. Kieran)

Dear Sir,

I have the pleasure of acknowledging receipt of your favor of 3rd inst., and to thank you for your courtesy and kindness in so promptly replying.

Your letter is the first intimation I have received about vacating the residence at the Eaton Lake School. Mr. A. Strong - Indian Agent - never referred to it when here last, nor have I had any communication of any kind from him.

I have never refused to leave this shack, as I was never asked to, and my position is simply this - I have no where to go, until I get something to do. I was not prepared for the position in which I find myself, as I had, perhaps, deluded myself in thinking, from
the remarks many times passed by Mr. Graham (then Indian Agent) that I would not be interfered with as I was carrying on as satisfactorily as I was.

I have no money - indeed I owe the local storekeeper $74.00, and at the moment I don't see how I am going to pay him, as I depended on my usual cheque coming. I tried to dispose of my Radio for which I paid $150.00, but failed, although it is a practically new machine. Had I known that I would lose the school position, I would not have bought it. Anyway, I am in a rather unenviable position, and I would not remain one minute here if I had anywhere else to go. I cannot remain inside during school hours, as I can neither read nor write or account of hearing every word spoken in the School Room, and I am afraid to make any noise lest it might disturb them - so I have to go out somewhere from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. I assure you it is heartbreaking wandering around.

P.S.

I may, perhaps, be allowed to make some remarks about this residence.

It was erected by Mr. Shergan - who was then teacher here - from scrap lumber, and in the usual inefficient way of an amateur. It is a ban to against the school. He bequeathed it to his successor, Mr. Kierman, from whom I inherited it. It was then not in a habitable condition - the rain was coming down almost everywhere, the roof being merely covered with tar paper. The entrance steps were broken down. I have added to it an extension of six or seven feet, and put in two windows, remodelled the entrance, and shingled the roof. The shingles cost me nothing, as there was enough remaining over.
over from the shingling of the School Room. These shingles were ordered before I came here, so that I had nothing to do with there being some over. Ottawa, January 27, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, relative to the continuing of the school for the benefit of the Indian children at Seton Lake (Shalalth).

In reply I beg to say it is noted that the Provincial Department of Education will be unable to continue their grant towards the salary of the teacher, and as you strongly urge that the school be continued and have nominated the services of Mrs. Burroughs to carry on the work until the end of June, next, the Department will approve of her appointment. In this connection I beg to confirm the following night lettergram to you of today's date:

"Engage Mrs. Burroughs as teacher Seton Lake School. Total salary of $60 per month will be allowed until end of June, next."

Please arrange with Mrs. Burroughs to begin duties as soon as possible. The sum of $60 per month is the total amount that we can pay her for her services. We note you consider that her qualifications would be satisfactory for the work at this school. Please inform the Department of the date on which she begins duties and also state her Christian name as this information is necessary in the drawing of cheques for her salary.

It may be that more white children will be available for the next school year beginning September 1st and that the Provincial Department of Education would then reconsider their decision and continue their grant towards the salary of the teacher. This question can, however, receive consideration in due time next summer.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lytton, B.C.

EXTRACT FROM INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY'S REPORT DATED SEPT. 24, 1934, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE SETON LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

The school is a small log building located on P.G.E. Railway Lands. A small rent is now being paid to the P.G.E. Railway for this land. When this was arranged a couple of years ago this school was a considerable distance from any other building. It was in fact in the Brush. Now owing to great activity in the Bridge River Gold Mines, the B. C. Electric town of Bridge River and the P.G.E. village of Shalalth have grown greatly. There are P.G.E. buildings right up to the edge of the school ground. This in addition to the increase of attendance would indicate that it would be much better to have a new school building located on the Indian Reserve and situated much nearer to the homes of the children. The Indian Agent has asked for a new school building for some years; but I would not recommend it previously. Conditions have so greatly changed that I am now willing to support the recommendation of the Indian Agent. The schoolhouse contains a schoolroom about 20' by 16', far too small for the 15 to 20 children who will be attending there this year, and a small badly lighted room attached in which some teachers have lived in the past. The present teacher rents a cottage near the school.

The Department provides $3.00 per month for the six months November to April for the provision of noon lunches for the children, some of whom come a long way to school. I wish to recommend the increase of this sum to $5.00 per month for the above months, and the sum of $3.00 per month for the months of September, October, May and June. Dr. MacQuarrie who visited the school shortly before I did asked me to make this recommendation, and I am very glad to be able to recommend this increase as the money is very badly required and the food given to the children is of great help to them.

In this connection I beg to inform you that the location of the above mentioned school is within the P.G.E. Right of Way through the Slosh Indian Reserve Seton Lake #1, and is therefore, only a few yards from the Reserve. The Indian Village is approximately one half mile distant from the school location, so in the event of a new school I would recommend it be erected on the Reserve. I would not consider it advisable to move the present school building as it is poorly constructed of logs and would, therefore, be difficult to enlarge to accommodate the increase in attendance.

Any benefits that may be gained would not justify the expenditure entailed in moving this building owing to its location and the contour of the land adjacent.

March 31st 1926

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

May I suggest to you the fact that the immediate need of a new school building here is a dire necessity.

An old log building built in 1923 is now overcrowded for the discard and has been repeatedly condemned by doctors. The school building which is nineteen feet by fifteen—houses twenty—one pupils—and hence is not in accordance with regulations that nine cubic feet should be allotted for each pupil. I have now an enrollment of twenty—one.
pupils, and Aprilst. the enrollment will be increased to twenty-five. Your department has been very generous in the distribution of medicine—cod liver oil etc., but come you here to see for yourself—the dilapidated school building—in which my poor pupils are forced to inhabit five hours of the day—you would readily agree—that more comfortable quarters—properly lighted—and properly ventilated—would do infinitely more—to further the good health of the pupils—as well as the happy environment in which to study.

I am sure if you refer this matter to our school Inspector, Mr. Curry—or, our Indian Agent, Mr. Strang—they will be glad—to testify to the immediate need of a new school building.
Thinking you for your kind consideration in the matter and hope for a favourable reply.

Remain,

Your very sincerely,

Christina Maclean.

Dear Sir:

With your letter of November 5, 1938, you forwarded a copy of Inspector Barry's report regarding his inspection of the Seton Lake Indian day school. The Inspector wrote in part as follows:

"The Seton Lake Indian Day School is carried on in a very old log shack. As previously reported you will find that the school building is located on the lands of the P.G.E. Railway Co., and that we pay a certain rent.

"Should it be decided to build a small modern school here such a school would of course not be located on the railway property, but on the Indian Reserve. A new school to accommodate at least thirty children is required just as soon as the Department can find the funds for its erection."

It is hoped to be able to provide funds in the supplementary estimates for the erection of a new school at this point and I should, therefore, appreciate your completing the enclosed data form.

"Secretary"
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Canada

Dear Sir:

I would like to suggest to you that the immediate need of a new school building here is a dire necessity.

The school, an old log building, is long overdue for the discard and has been repeatedly condemned by doctors.

The school building, which is twenty feet long by sixteen feet wide and nine feet high, houses seventeen pupils. After September the enrollment will probably be increased to twenty. Hence the school is not in accordance with regulations that each person should have 3000 cubic feet per hour.

Your Department has been so very generous in the distribution of medicine that if ever you
here to see for yourself the dilapidated school in which my poor pupils are forced to inhabit five hours of the day, you would readily agree that more comfortable quarters, properly lighted and ventilated, would do infinitely more to further the children's good health as well as a happy environment in which to study and play.

I am sure if you refer this important matter to the school inspector, Captain Barry, or to our Agent, Mr. Strong, they will be glad to testify to the immediate need of a new school building.

Thanking you for your kind consideration in the matter, I am hoping for a favorable reply.

Yours very sincerely,

Florence A. Russell

PROPOSED BUILDING DATA

NAME OF BUILDING: Seton Lake (Shalalth) Indian Day School
LOCATION: Seton Lake I.R. No. 1
PROVINCE: British Columbia

BRANCH: Indian Affairs
DATE: June 6, 1935.

APPROPRIATION:
VOTE:

RECOMMEND CONSTRUCTION BY: BAYBERGER
CONTRACT:

REASON: CLASS OF INDIAN DAY LABOUR AVAILABLE.
Indians unskilled labourers. Contract should require their employment as far as possible.

BUILDING REQUIREMENTS: ROOMS AND ACCOMMODATION; NUMBER OF PUPILS;
TYPE OF CONSTRUCTION:
Frame building consisting of one schoolroom to accommodate up to thirty pupils, the usual cloak rooms, and two small rooms, one to be used as a room for vocational training of girls and one for the storage of drugs and as a dispensary.

DESCRIPTION OF SITE AND CONDITIONS; SUBMIT PLAN; NORTH POINT;
NATURE OF SOIL, DRAINAGE REQUIREMENTS AND ANY OTHER PARTICULARS.
On a hill side within about one hundred yards of Seton Lake but not on P.G.E. property. The soil is rocky with natural drainage.

WATER SUPPLY: SYSTEM REQUIRED; SOURCE OF WATER, ETC.
Present supply is from Seton Lake by bucket, about one hundred yards from and a hundred feet below school.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6411, file 841-5, part 3)

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
TOILET FACILITIES: SEWAGE DISPOSAL; SYSTEM REQUIRED; LOCATION.
Two outdoor toilets. Pits would have to be dug or excavated.

HEATING SYSTEM: TYPE OF FURNACE OR BOILER; FUEL.
Hot air furnace to take wood and with two pipes to schoolroom and one to each of other rooms.

LIGHTING SYSTEM: SOURCE OF POWER; SPECIAL REQUIREMENTS.
B.C. Electric lines are available near site but electric light is perhaps not essential although present school is very dark. Owing to high mountains, winter lighting is poor and very large windows will be necessary.

BUILT-IN EQUIPMENT REQUIRED: BLACKBOARD AREA; CUPBOARDS, ETC.
Two large cupboards. Usual asbestoslate or equivalent blackboards four feet wide around two sides of schoolroom. Windows should occupy whole of one side and cupboards and doors the remaining end. Facing the end of the room with blackboard, windows should be on left and rest of blackboard on the right, doors and cupboards at rear. This is the standard arrangement as light must come over left shoulder of pupil.

SHIPPING INSTRUCTIONS FOR MATERIALS: NEAREST SHIPPING POINT
LOCAL TRANSPORTATION FACILITIES TO SITE, ETC.
Shalalth is on the Pacific Great Eastern Railway. There is no road for motor vehicles from Lillooet to Shalalth. Automobiles are freighted from Lillooet on flat cars to Shalalth when on their way to the Bridge River mining area. There is a poor road from the Shalalth P.G.E. Railway yards to the possible site of the new school, but motor trucks could manage this short haul quite well.

REMARKS:
The site for this school should be carefully selected, with care to secure satisfactory recreation ground. No accommodation necessary for teachers.

Would suggest full concrete basement, with windows to provide light for manual training.

Basement should provide room for hot air furnace, manual training shop and wood storage.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the construction of the new Indian Day School at Seton Lake I. R. No. 1, I would advise that investigation of this Reserve showed that there were no unoccupied building sites, the Pacific Great Eastern Railway for some reason having been permitted to take a right-of-way obviously in excess of railway requirements, thereby taking nearly all the fairly level land on the Reserve.

The most suitable site from the point of exposure, drainage, general accessibility, and offering the most suitable recreation ground facilities on the Reserve, had been partly cleared, fenced and a house erected by the occupant, Sandy Shields, an Indian of the Band. In order to take advantage of this site, it would be necessary to move his house on to a piece of adjoining land, which is not large enough for the School and exposed to the prevailing winds. This property was thoroughly inspected by Messrs. Inspectors Coleman and Barry and Mr. Agent Strang, and it was considered that the minimum valuation of same was, as follows:

Clearing...........$50.00
Fencing............50.00
Interest in good site.......150.00
Cost moving and re-erecting house...100.00
$350.00

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, ONT.
But the Indian has expressed willingness to accept $300.00 for his interest in the land and cost of moving his dwelling, which is considered most reasonable under the circumstances, and I enclose herewith resolution by the Band setting the site aside for School purposes, and acceptance of $300.00 compensation by the Indian occupant, Sandy Shields, which I would recommend for approval, with the request that I be advised in the matter as soon as possible as the contractors are anxious to proceed with the work before the advent of winter weather.

I would request that at least $200.00 of this compensation be met from the School Vote and, if necessary, I could purchase lumber, etc., required for the re-erection of the Indian's house from the funds set aside for new buildings and repairs to Indian houses, and would request authorization to proceed to expend whatever is necessary in this connection owing to the lateness of the season and the necessity of housing the Indian's large family without undue delay. If the full compensation is paid in cash, this authorization will not be required.

I would appreciate your instructions by return airmail.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,

Lytton, B.C.,
April 10, 1940

Sir,

I beg to submit herewith my voucher No. 1121Y covering an account from Mr. Ira C. Jones, building contractor of Vancouver, B.C., in connection with an extra toilet which he constructed at the new Seton Lake day school. Mr. Jones had the contract to build the new school.

Last December it was thought that if funds were available an extra toilet for the use of the teacher might be provided at the school. Tenders were asked from Mr. Jones and another contractor and the matter was submitted to Major Mackay, Indian Commissioner for B.C. who later advised that no funds were then available for such an expenditure. The matter was then dropped. However, at the end of January this year, Mr. Jones submitted his account for $40.00 for the cost of constructing a third toilet at the school and I notified him the account could not be forwarded for payment as the expenditure had not been authorized. Mr. Jones admitted in his letter accompanying the account that he had not been instructed to build this toilet but that as there were three built at the Creekside school, he would take the chance of building the extra one at Seton Lake.

It would seem that provision in the beginning for an extra toilet for the use of the teacher would have been desirable and I would therefore respectfully recommend the account be approved if funds are available. Mr. Jones' tender on the construction of the building was the lower of the two received.

Your obedient servant,

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
